Your crew is not up to the challenge. The first volley of cannonballs glides over the pirate ship and, quite remarkably, manages to miss the ship, its sails, and its masts. The attackers retaliate with their own cannons and the sea becomes a stage for your explosive exchanges. When the smoke clears, both ships are ruined and the pirates scamper away. Your crew celebrates their victory while trying to ignore the extensive damage.
Prepare to board!

A present for Davy Jones, and booty for your crew. Your sailors are fighters by nature, and the ramshackle pirate crew is no match for them. What few scoundrels oppose the assault are sent to greet the fishes and the others are forced to surrender - your crew plunders their ship but find little loot on the decrepit vessel. It is pity more than mercy that makes them spare the pirates.

There's no denying your crew's lack of strength. The sailors throw themselves at the pirates with a noticeable will to fight but hardly enough skill to fulfil their dreams of domination. The scrawny pirates beat the crew and leave, slightly less bruised and weary than their victims but too drained and wounded to linger on your ship.

Too hasty. Your helmsman is used to conventional manoeuvres only, and steering the ship while its anchor is still grazing the sea floor is beyond his nautical comprehension. The entire ship shakes and swirls, drifting over the waves in a violent jump which sends it crashing into the pirate ship. The scoundrels board you!
Fight till the decimation of either crew

An underwhelming victory. Yes, your crew manages to gain the upper hand over the pirates and displays decent self-control and fighting skill, but the pirates are far from their image of wondrous sea fighters. They are weak. The skeletal attackers scatter as your sailors crush them, and your broken deck is littered with scrawny corpses. The repairs take a lesser toll on morale than the gnawing pity your crew feels for the scoundrels.

Your sailors' desperation is no match for the pirates'. The attackers pour from the carcass of their ship, oblivious to the large faults in the wood, flowing like blood from a wound. They wash over your sailors, who scatter in their current, unable to oppose resistance and too weak to even consider it. When the wave of pirates recedes, your deck is covered in fragments of both ship and men.
Listen to reason and surrender

This should have been done much earlier. Your weapons are dropped just in time for the pirates to stop their assault. They spare the crew in exchange for a decent quantity of loot - however, their mercy will never give back the men lost to your hazardous manoeuvres and their outstanding failure.
That's enough risk-taking: surrender

A refusal to fight. Bound by their code of honour, the pirates spurn the idea of killing any of the surrendering sailors and help themselves to your supplies. The shabby scoundrels celebrate their meagre plunder with glee and leave your crew riddled with pity for their attackers.
Let them come, rouse the spirit of the crew with a speech

There is faith in the upcoming victory. Your acting lieutenant climbs the rail guard and points his gun at the skies, defying the heavens themselves. I am weak, vulnerable, he says, like well-born men are - but while my body is feeble my heart is that of a captain, and your captain no less. And like you sailors I will fight, and I will fight to the death, and I will continue to fight after this death, for not a single pirate will lay a single finger on our ship, in this life or in the next!
Board the pirates' ship!

A fantastic charge. Led by the acting lieutenant, your sailors hurtle down the boarding bridges and storm the pirate ship, leaving a trail of mangled scoundrels in their wake. The black flag is torn from its mast and the pirate booty is plundered. Taken by a sudden generosity, your crew lets the survivors scurry away with their wreck of a vessel. They might be the last pirates alive.

Your sailors' strength is mental only. They lack both the skill and speed required for a quick take-down of the boarded ship, and allow the pirates to regroup behind makeshift barricades of crates and sacks of goods.
Take cover and shoot from a distance

The pirate ship is a playground for your crew. They avoid the shots of the scoundrels with ease and take cover, burying behind overthrown barrels of rum and taking down the pirates, accurate shot by accurate shot. When not a single enemy is left standing, your ship recovers its crew and leaves - victorious, but drenched in the smell of alcohol and gunpowder.

Your crew is ill-prepared for this challenge. The sailors run around in circles, unable to settle on a good cover while the pirates shoot at will, taking them down with ease. The remaining members of your crew are spared in exchange of their cargo, and your expedition takes a toll from this loss.
Continue your charge!

A manifestation of their true skill. Despite its initial fumbling, your crew manages to reach the pirates' covers and forces its way through the barricades, overpowering the scoundrels in a matter of minutes. Not a single pirate is left standing, and as few sailors as possible suffered the same fate. It was the best they could do.

Stubbornness will not trigger miracles. Still proving how unskilled and weak they are, your sailors crash upon the pirates' barricade like foam upon the shore, and the gunshots scatter them across the deck. The pirates meet no resistance when they raid your ship, and the survivors shamelessly thank their attackers for taking nothing more than cargo.
Fire all cannons!

Flawless victory. The volley of cannonballs demolishes the pirate ship's flanks, each projectile aimed at the most mould-ridden parts of the wood. The antique vessel collapses on itself and your sailors have but to watch the pirates drown then loot the flotsam at will.

Was this aimed at the pirates or the actual sky? Your cannonballs fly way over the pirate ship and allow the scoundrels to react to your bold, but uncontrolled manoeuvre. The tide of the battle shifts in their favour as grappling hooks catch your ship and lock it into place.
Defend against the boarding pirates

Today is not the day you are vanquished by pirates. The attackers barely set foot on deck that your sailors launch their assault, a coordinated charge grinded into perfection by years of practice. Still, the pirates resist to the best of their ability, and their desperate foray costs the lives of a few good men.

Disaster. The courage of your sailors is not matched by their force, and the pirates wash through them like a wave through sand. When the attackers finally decide that culling your crew is not worth their time, the remaining sailors do not dare retaliate and simply stand their ground, keeping watch on their wrecked ship and devastated pride.
Surrender to them

A refusal to fight. Bound by their code of honour, the pirates spurn the idea of killing any of the surrendering sailors and help themselves to your supplies. The shabby scoundrels celebrate their meagre plunder with glee and leave your crew riddled with pity for their attackers.

There's no spirit nor courage to be roused. Your crew barely reacts to your lieutenant's speech, hypnotized by the approaching pirate ship, entranced by their terror. The attackers board the ship and everything is both too fast and too slow: the massacre of the resisting sailors, the looting, the pirates' departure. When the crew regains its senses, they realize the price of their cowardice.
The Ghost Ship

After weeks of hot weather, supplies of drinking water have become dangerously low. It therefore seems a minor miracle when a fellow ship appears on the horizon, for surely they have water to share? But as it draws near, the crew is aghast, for there is no sign of life aboard. 'It is a ghost ship, we must flee before it is too late!' they cry.
Send a diver to check it out

The diver does remarkably to spot the fiends furled in sails, or waiting under barrels to ambush, should your men have boarded. Your ship draws alongside the vessel as if to pass, but then unleashes enough cannon-fire to drown it. The crew are elated, believing they have done the oceans a great service.
Heathen superstition! Board the ship!
Heavens shine upon you, for whatever caused the crew to vacate this ship seems no longer a concern. Better yet, the lord has seen fit to provide the water you seek.
The ship's hold contains an unholy mound of corpses. 'God hath forsaken these men', says the doctor, 'but how?'
Have the doctor investigate what happened
'We are lucky indeed, for malaria cannot reach us now.' says the doctor confidently. This swift diagnosis confirms the crew are pleased to load up the drinking water they have been gasping for.

'Touch nothing! Get off the ship,' frets the doctor, who believes a dreadful plague has taken the crew of this ill-fated vessel. Perhaps drinking water is itself the cause. The crew are miserable time has been wasted, and that their thirst is still not slaked.

The doctor is inconsolable, 'it is plague. I lanced a bubo, and it ruptured suddenly upon my person!' That the water be contaminated is misery enough, but to have to abandon the good doctor is a disaster! Your expedition drifts glumly on.
Leave the ship immediately

No relief at escaping the grotesque mound of corpses, can compensate the terrible thirst of your crew. There are murmurings that no such expedition can succeed if 'gift horses always be looked in the mouth.'

The crew are so faithless, that every creaking plank aboard the ghostly ship raises a whimper. So when a banshee howl erupts from below deck, every sailor runs for their life. One poor soul trips in a coil of rigging and cracks their head upon an iron capstan. The death exposes all the more the crew's foolishness.
Leave and hope to find an island with drinking water soon

No relief at escaping the disturbingly empty ship, can compensate the terrible thirst of your crew. There are murmurings that no such expedition can succeed if 'gift horses always be looked in the mouth.'
Terrifyingly, the ship takes after yours in pursuit. Who knows what dread hands operate its multifarious controls!
Try to outrun the awful vessel!
Your ship manages to escape the ghoulish clutches of that unwholesome adversary, but have no drinking water, or anything else, to show for the ordeal.

Your ship is not agile enough. Men pour into the waves from where enemy cannons punch holes. Seemingly contented with this sacrifice, the dread sentience commanding the vessel calls off its dreadful pursuit.
Turn and face it, whatever it is!

Pirates! But trickery cannot match the power of a modern seaship! Summarily demolished, a few of them are left clinging to wreckage. They beg to join your cause - unpaid. Such are the dwindling prospects of piracy in this day! The crew will jibe at them, but secretly all must be elated to have acquired such sea-wisdom for free.

A pirate nuisance! Though their scurvy deception gives them advantage, they are like many of their creed, rather jaded. By the time their ship is sunk, it has cost you a few good men. Yet the recovery of precious drinking water in among the flotsam, assuages the grief of your crew.

Bloody pirates! A terrible menace even in this day and age! Your crew are outmanoeuvred, outsmarted, and your ship is reeled-in for boarding. Many are killed in valiant defence of the company, but to no avail. Your vessel is duly ransacked for supplies, before the villains are again on their way.
The Visitation

An undesirable visitor haunts the ship. Fleeting silhouettes, knocking and screeching sounds. Each morning the ship appears in utter disarray. 'A night fiend,' gulps the hardiest of old crewmen, as he sweeps debris from the deck. As night draws in again, you realise something must be done.
Listen to your expert

Every right to a little joke. 'These claw marks!' the naturalist feigns horror. 'Is it something terrible?!' asks a fearful sailor. But the naturalist can bite tongue no longer, and succumbs to laughter; 'No! Good heavens. We have a mother and kittens aboard!' The cat family is found in a barrel, which, it is agreed, shall serve as their home for the duration. The crew dote on the little rascals, their presence a great comfort.
Perform an exorcism

Each sailor strides with inner conviction, as they form a procession of candles behind the smug-looking priest, flooding holy light into every heathen crevice. The priest's ritual is unfaltering, and not only are the crew rid of the night-time menace, but now believe it is god's plan the expedition will succeed.

The crew has its sceptics, even though the exorcism seems at first to have worked. Two days later a sailor cries, 'It had glowing yellow eyes!' upon having sighted the demon near the hold. The unholy thing must be caught.
Bait the thing with food

It is nothing so savage. All are concealed around the strip of meat, expecting the worst. But what descends from the rafters of the hold, silent and gentle winged, is a luminous white owl. It is an ambiguous omen, according to those that know, but the sailors are content to keep it aboard.

Whatever it is, it is far too clever. It avoids the bait, but continues its night raids. Rumour this is an offended Klabautermann are substantiated by several separate accounts. Little voices overheard, brief sightings, even the discovery of a miniature table and chair. Some can live with the impish nuisance, but many will jump ship at the next port..
Build a trap to catch the thing

The cage-trap is well-made, and daybreak reveals an unlikely specimen encaged. 'A sort of badger?' is the first analysis, which in actuality, is fairly far from the mark. The compendium of animalia in the ship's library reveals it a 'northern raccoon', also remarking that is 'quite edible.'

The snapping trap is weak and flimsy. The crew are excited by a sharp sound, but rush to the scene, only to find the bait gone, and the trap in disrepair. A piece of bright red felt caught in the spring explains all. 'Klabautermann!' they despair, for it is a terrible omen to offend a sea goblin as they have done.

The crew don't have much belief, and the priest makes a hash of the exorcism. If anything, his fragmented delivery only agitates the creature. The next night, a sailor is adamant he has sighted something 'irrefutably demonic.'
Gather arms and confront it

Rather excessive. The soldiery tense as strange noises draw near. Fingers itch upon triggers. The moment demon wings flap into view, the night is lit up with powder. Finally the smoke subsides, and the mangled thing is revealed to be nothing more than a bat. Troops thunder heavily about the ship, before discovering the rest of the hog-nosed critters in the hold. Everyone is left feeling utterly stupid.

Your lily-livered cowards quiver like jelly! Fear chokes them as they spin wildly about looking for something to shoot that they can't see. Two are so panicked they bump together, causing the other to suddenly fire. Shot hits an angelic young sailor, killing instantly. The night terror is gone, but has taken for payment the most undeserving of souls.
Sate the demon with a sacrificial offering

A man's finger for a stowaway weasel! In good faith, a pious sailor volunteers the pinkie of his right hand as a votive offering. But at the smell of blood, it is a slinky little mustelid that appears. With the weasel caught and caged, the night terror is over, but the sailors will not forgive or forget the loss of a good man's finger.

Sacrilege! A prohibited tome is consulted, the vile solicitations of its pages consuming the crew! Unspeakable acts are performed upon a man, so that the demon can be assuaged. Yet still the menace remains, and worse, the crew's sacrificial victim bleeds out from his injuries.
Don't anger the creature further

The practical joke is ruined. The bored sailors bemoan the pathetic response to their little entertainment. That the senior officers have been duped by an obvious ruse, makes all severely doubt their fitness to lead.

The faithless crew never take any part of the exorcism seriously. 'What's the point of hocus-pocus when its but greedy sailors stealing?!' yells one man. Accusations fly between conspiracy theorists, until a violent brawl breaks out. At the next mooring, the injured parties desert your godless expedition.
Find the culprit

Your sharp-nosed hunters pick up a scent. Pungent droppings demarcate a perimeter, in the centre of which is a crate with a hole. A sailor reaches his arm bravely in. There is a brief struggle, and a whine like the ones at night, before the troublemaker is pulled out. It is a common garden fox. The cunning little creature becomes the crew's talisman for the remainder of the expedition.

Hunters find tracks, but can't say what made them. The marks are indeed strange - disturbing almost. Claw marks that go deep in the decking, as if the unspeakable thing that made them was in some frenzy.
Smoke it out of hiding

Reassuringly human coughing comes from within. It turns out you have a stowaway - a young girl wishing to escape a life of hardship. She is spirited., and the crew take to her quickly. She is given work to do, and food to eat. All believe she shall prove their good luck charm.
Build a trap to catch whatever it is

Knowing its habits helps. The box is made to measure, and along with its clever latch, is placed where the fiend seems most often to be. The box is found in the morning, with a gigantic rat inside it. The trap appears to have killed it, and that is the end of the matter.

The ramshackle trap box is in bits the next morning. While to some they appear benign, the claw marks appear more frequently. Once a man wakes with his cheeks gouged. Some are so perturbed by the night demon, that they slink off the ship at the next available harbour.
Pray together against the spirit

A feeling of calm descends upon the crew. The prayer seems to fill the spiritual void in the sailor's breasts. Approaching the world with a new perspective means even if the unexplained episodes at night persist, they pay it no mind.

The communal prayer is broken by more wild shrieking. It matters not that, apart from vanishing supplies, the mischievous spirit seems fairly harmless. The crew are deeply troubled, and worry their souls are lost.

The hunters stumble guilelessly into its trap. The night is unfeasibly pitch, and the hunters' lamps extinguish. Who knows why, without a breath of wind? A scratching draws near. Then a commotion... and screaming, followed by silence. Just like that, the fiend has gone forever, returning to the air whence it came. Three men lie dead in their own blood. Their livers have been removed.
Ignore the menace
The menace is very persistent. Restless nights, devoured food, and stolen supplies shall go unexplained and unresolved for the remainder of the expedition. The crew are at their wit's end.
Baptism of Fire

Everything points towards the foreboding gate. Salvation lies beyond, but the eerie blue flame that suffuses it keep the crew at a distance. Perhaps it would be safer to find a way through the surrounding jungle, but those of faith say the gate is 'an auspicious sign'.
Have the scientist look at the gate
Have faith and leap through the flames.
Wrap up before leaping through the flames.
Cut through the jungle instead

The scientist banishes the illusion. 'This fire that you perceive around the gate, is simply the agglomeration of azure glow-worms.' Laughter becomes delight, as the party take the pulsing creatures in hand. This is the wonder of nature.

If anything the flames are cool, almost like bundles of ribbons brushing the skin. This gate is, without question, an earthly manifestation of the divine. Ahead, an extremely hospitable settlement affirms the holy blessing.

The doubtful crew are surprised. Drawing closer to the gate, they find the flames seem to give off no heat. One leap of faith and they are through! Still they hesitate, for a perfect skeleton sits propped against it.

Fire and brimstone! The heat is intense, but your procession of false prophets seem numb to the pain. The others watch horrified, as fabric, skin and flesh renders before their eyes. If the expedition continues, it will only be for the mercy of god.
Determine how the person died
Order them to charge through!

The doctor forms a reasonable hypothesis, but cannot be absolutely sure from bone alone. 'The way they sit suggests they lacked the will to continue.' Not wishing to end the same way, the crew are astonished to discover that leaping through the gate does them no harm.

The doctor's career is over. As are the careers of those who heed his words. 'Came through from the other side, but it was not the fire that took him'. As they jump, flames grasp their ankles, and rapidly shoot up and over the rest.
'Ouch!' The men yelp, rolling in the dirt until they are sure they are no longer afire. The strange arch behind them, your brave soldiers compare their battle scars.
'Cowards!' Your men lack the military discipline to follow a simple order! You will have to find another way.
They make it. Rolled-up like carpets they skip through the flaming gate. Their worst complaint is the sweet and overwhelming pong of sweat that now follows them.
'That they died as sausages! or what shall we tell their families!?' Perhaps dousing their mantles in a protective layer of paraffin was a mistake! Your expedition continues to turn on its spit.
The crew have no regrets in plotting such a rational course. Sweaty jungles are the devil they know, crawling with tentacle limb and spider fang. But who knew what sorcery governed that strange gate?
The jungle thins out to a precipice. A long and shoddy-looking bridge stretches to the other side, or else you could attempt to find a way around.

No way through, thanks to your shambolic mapreading. The group becomes separated, and eventually lost. Hacking those ancient and contorted roots has saved no time that couldn't be saved by backtrack, and cost you several lives into the bargain.
Inspect the bridge
Circumnavigate the cliff
It is in passable condition. There are a few nerve-wracking moments, as the wind whips the bridge into a vigorous sway, and all are rather pleased to reach the other side. Your expedition continues.

Most treacherous! The confidence of your craftsmen in the rickety structure couldn't be more misplaced. Of course it is nothing if not dramatic, when the bridge cables twang, and one after the other pile into the gorge.
It is a long trek, that could have been much longer but for the competence of those with a compass. Yet another hiccup for the expedition log book.
Imbecile orienteers! There is no other way across this river valley for a hundred miles! You have covered half that distance before you realise, wasting a lot of time and provisions.
Songs Under the Sea

The lookout is sure of himself: he saw a mermaid. Despite the burning sun of noon, sailors pile up against the ship's handrails and inspect the mirror waters for more signs of the creature. At last, they glimpse its silver tail and hear its song, a mesmerizing chant which beckons them.
Have an expert examine the apparition

The mermaid is half-fish, half-fish. The scientist orchestrates a careful operation to retrieve the animal from the ocean, sending divers underwater to lure and catch the creature by playing with it. The miniature whale enjoys singing with your sailors for the rest of the trip.
Answer the mermaid with a sailing chant

Not one, but a dozen mermaids answer the chant. As your crew sings of their country ruling the waves and their patriots never being slaves, the marine creatures react joyfully and surround the ship, jumping along its sides. These animals are no mermaids. They're frisky little whales!
Try to catch one of them

An effortless catch for your fishermen. Taking care not to hurt the beautiful creatures, the sailors casts multiple nets in the water and retrieve an individual from the pack, quickly transferring it to one of your wildlife aquariums. The animal seems to enjoy the constant attention and the free food, and the crew falls in love with the playful "mermaid."

Your fishermen are not used to catching fish alive. They cast a weighted nest among the pack, but as they try to pull it up the animal slips out, its tangled flipper striped with thin red lines. The creatures flee underwater, leaving the sailors longing for their song.
Leave the creatures be

The moment is otherworldly. The creatures dance among the waves, tweeting and clicking in response to your sailors' cheers, jumping higher with each new verse sung by their human admirers. Their ballet and innocent happiness is well worth the absence of mermaids.

The mermaid vanishes. The crew sings with more passion than prowess, and the creature itself doesn't deign to answer. When at last their breath is short, the sailors mourn the disappearance of the mermaid and waste more time dreaming up her sisters and their underwater kingdoms.

A sailor jumps into the ocean! Unfazed by the crew's heartfelt singing and longing for her, the mermaid flips her tail, teasing and staying underwater. Spurred by the chanting, one of your men leaps into the sea and is now gurgling and splashing in a parody of swimming technique, desperate to follow the creature.
Go after the mermaid and the drifting sailor

Close enough for one last glimpse of the mermaid. The ship slides aside the creature and the frenzied sailor swimming after it. The mermaid splashes her tail at her stalker and disappears, allowing the fallen man to be dragged back onboard, where he is immediately pressed by jealous questions. Alas, the sailor saw little of the frightened creature and its true form remains a mystery.

The maneuver sends the ship crashing against both man and mermaid. Too eager to catch up with the beautiful creature, several sailors grapple the steering wheel and fight to guide the ship, oblivious to the alarmed instructions of their officers. The iron prow crushes the mermaid and her follower. When they come to their senses, the sailors are not punished: their horror and shame is sanction enough.
Let the fool face his fate

The smitten sailor drowns. The man paddles against the light waves, his skull going in and out of the water, his lips moving feverishly and the sea sounds keeping his words for themselves. When his head doesn't resurface, the sailors know the mermaid had nothing to do with it.
Convince the sailors of ignoring the creature

Discipline is stronger than fascination. Galvanized by the orders of their officers, the sailors ignore the mermaid's calls and leave it behind, fulfilling their duty. They feel like heroes of ancient tales in the face of mystical temptations and the epic trial makes them shiver in pride.

Fascination gets the better of your crew's discipline. The men ignore all orders and deliberate among themselves, planning the best approach to catch the mermaid's attention. The officers cannot accept this undermining of their authority, and get the whips ready.
Give the dissidents a good flogging

Action commands respect. Four of the most unruly sailors are dragged to the stern, tied in kneeling positions, and flogged until their shirts are drenched. Acceptance spreads within the crew as their minds clear, and they resume their duties knowing that this expedition will tolerate no mischief. The mermaid was a nice but short-lived dream.

The flogging exceeds discipline and goes overboard. Instead of organizing a session of punishment, with explicit rules, blames and sanctions, the officers chastise at will, whipping whoever is within reach, spitting their anger in unintelligible tirades. When they calm down, the dissidents are a mass of sweat, blood, and whimpers. The mermaid cries in the distance as the crew resumes its duties.
Drop the issue and let them be

Discipline aboard this ship is lax. Convinced that their misconduct can go unpunished, the sailors take to ignore or bargain the officers' orders, and "mermaid" becomes a keyword to rally against tedious instructions. This behaviour plagues the rest of the trip.
The Devil Calls

Human voices call through the uninhabited rainforest. With each new step through the humid air and dense trees, the sailors unconsciously stand closer to their priest. Rumours of the evil one's presence made them laugh when protected by the comfort of the ship but investigating the forest itself is something else. As a child's voice babbles in the distance, the priest urges the sailors to ignore it.
Have your zoologist inspect the surroundings

The sailors were lured by the song of a bird. Through careful scrutiny of the rainforest's ground, the zoologist finds a curious brown ball hopping under the fern, its tail spread into aerial and colourful feathers. What they heard wasn't the call of the devil, but the mating song of a bird. Amazed by the creature's ability to perfectly replicate human voice, the sailors eagerly capture it to share its marvels with the world.
Ignore the voice as the priest advises

The priest's advice works. Blocking their ears and closing their hearts to the crying voice, the sailors run from the cursed place. When they allow themselves to hear again, the voices are gone and their faith is renewed, stronger than ever. Whether this call was the devil's or not, their resistance is worth celebrating.

The voice is too persistent to be ignored. The youthful cries haunt the sailors, and they advance through the rainforest half wanting to understand its cause, half wishing they never do. They try to light torches to reveal the evil, but the damp atmosphere snuffs them out. As day advances and nights steps in, so does the voice get closer to the men.
Have the priest face the invisible menace

The priest's voice is louder than the devil's.
"Surely God is my salvation,
I will trust and not be afraid.
The Lord, the Lord himself, is my strength and my defence, He has become my salvation."
The priest's chant resonates through the moist air, reverberating deep into the forest's darkness. Whether there was evil to be fought or not, the holy chant certainly silenced its call.

The priest's attempts do not match the menace. As he anoints each sailor with hastily blessed water, a voice identical to his laughs from the depths of the forest. After a night spent without light nor sleep, the sailors realize several of them are missing. They will never know if this was desertion or abduction.
Run away to the ship

The devil's call is covered by the sailors' screams. They hurtle down the rainforest with the speed of possessed men and rush inside the ship, desperate for its protection. They can never quite explain their misadventure, and become a regular targets of jokes for those who did not hear the devil.
Ignore the advice and look for a rational explanation

The hunters patiently let the voice come to them. Knowing better than to ruffle through the thick vegetation and scare the wildlife away, the sailors stay still until a bird no bigger than a fist emerges from the fern and tweets excitedly, emitting the songs of a variety of other birds, along with human noises and voices. Delighted, the hunters decide to bring the little marvel back onboard.

The sailors are not discreet hunters. They rummage through the forest, so mindful of the voice they lack focus. A man walks on a tail and the giant lizard it belongs to jerks out of its leafy camouflage, rushing to climb a bystander as if it were a tree. Reacting to the movement, more beasts emerge from the ground and attack, their bites causing profuse bleeding and screaming. The crew flees in horror, convinced of the devil's presence.
The Treasure of Hassan Ben Sahid

Are you ready for real treasure hunting? What was set to be a routine stop at an inland tavern turned out to have a much grander potential: an elder invited your crew to join her on her hunt for the cache of the corsair Hassan Ben Sahid. The find is all she needs, she says, and she'd gladly trade the satisfaction of ending a lifelong quest against the treasure itself. Your crew bursts in excitement. A pirate treasure!
Follow the beckoning elder

The complete trust of your crew puts the old woman at ease. A youthful spark lights her eyes as she drags your men through the town and into her hideout, a shack whose walls and floor are covered in travelling gear for all weathers. The only furniture of the place is a table which displays a map crumbling from too much usage. The plan is old and its indications are coded, the woman points out, but she's already worked out a link with the current town.
Decode the map's indications

Knowledge of tongues can make texts talk. Your diplomats work their way through the cyphers, piecing Oriental alphabets together with Latin grammatical logic. The indications do point to the current region, but rather than a precise location, the deciphered text offers an enigma:
"Hassan Ben Sahid salutes you with his last breath.
Upon you the gifts of true solace and rebirth,
While I lay asleep in the lavish lap of earth.
May mercy find you despite my earliest death."
This is spiritual: go inspect the local church

The treasure of Hassan Ben Sahid! The old explorer leads your crew to the church. A sailor, muttering about Ben Sahid's riddle of solace and rebirth, scrutinizes the Christ crucified above the altar and soon finds a loose stone in the wall behind it. Brick by brick the wall is dismantled to reveal rusty iron daggers, ancient silver chalices, shinning gold coins. As the old woman marvels over the Moor pirate's piety and the end of her quest, she insists that the treasure be your crew's.

<b>If there is a treasure to be found, it's not here.<b> The old woman leads your sailors to the local church and they inspect the weathered building and its surrounding, but they don't see what Ben Sahid's riddle about rebirth may mean. Perhaps they simply lack the knowledge needed? The search is vain and the crew settles on enjoying the old explorer's tales of adventure, as both her and the sailors try to ignore their lingering feeling of near-accomplishment.
This is straightforward: go inspect the cemetery

The treasure of Hassan Ben Sahid! Both crew and old explorer inspect every single tomb, looking for the solution to the pirate's riddle. At last a sailor points out a grave bearing not two, but a single year: an infant dead before it could live - or, as Ben Sahid put it, the earliest death. Instead of a corpse, they find jewels and gold in the casket. The old woman weeps before the end of her quest, takes a single gem, and gracefully invites your crew to take the treasure.

The search is fruitless. The graves all look the same. Knowing the solution lies in the pirate's riddle and its mention of the earliest death, the crew tries to find the most ancient tomb, but with age comes erosion and the dates are barely legible - this is not what the riddle meant. The sailors are forced to abandon this dead end and settle on the idea that this is as far as anyone ever got to Hassan Ben Sahid's treasure.

The texts refuse to speak to the crew. The sailors inspect the ink, place mirrors in front of what could be letters, bring a flame so close it could burn the wrinkled paper, and trigger the ire of the old explorer. She ushers the brutish crew away from her precious plan and thanks them cooly: next time, they should show more adequacy for the task they're attempting. She closes her door on her hideout and the promise of treasure.
Match the map to the surrounding landscape

A treasure cache! Following the coast's silhouette and how it transcribes to the map, the sailors manage to find what places Hassan Ben Sahid found worthy of his time: the local church, a former red district and a suspiciously plain cliff above the sea. Indeed, the cliff is slit by a large opening which leads to a cave where the crew finds scattered riches - maybe not the full extent of the pirate's treasure, but a remarkable find nonetheless.

The crew finds nothing but rocks and grasshoppers. The sailors engage on a hunt to match any coastline, forest or flower bush to the map's drawings. In a final attempt to uncover Ben Sahid's cache, a sailor overturns a stone that absolutely looked like it belonged to the plan and discovers a simmering campfire: the insects grilling over the coals make for a weird, if enjoyable reward, but they are far from the promised riches.

The hag leads your crew into a trap! Before they can realize how misplaced their trust was, the sailors are stuck between the sides of a narrow alley, armed men in front, armed men in back. They make it clear that the only treasure they're looking for is yours.
Attack the crooks

Your sailors are the ones who do the beatings. Acting like one, they fire before the cutpurses can react and overwhelm them in a matter of minutes, getting the bandits to beg for their lives. The taste of victory is dampened by how effortless it was to fool the crew, and they regain the ship with sour moods.

Your sailors are defeated without difficulty. The members of this crew are not fighters to begin with and their lack of ability shows in their poor coordination, whereas the bandits' organization is almost military-like. They suppress your sailors without a second thought, and the rare survivors are left to plod back to their ship.
Surrender some of your possessions
The thugs watch as your crew empties their pockets.
Accept

You trade several goods against safe passage. Trade is a strong word for this parody of consent, and your sailors feel ridiculed. They blame themselves for having believed in these tall tales of pirate treasures and leave with a little less belief in the extraordinary.
Cancel

What the crew offers is far from enough. The old woman barely glances at the goods presented to her before flicking her wrist, triggering a rain of bullets onto the sailors. When she snaps her fingers to signal the end of the assault, your would-be adventurers are either wounded or dead. The survivors drag themselves back to the ship and rumours of treasures can never excite them again.
Ignore the promise of riches

Tales of pirate treasures belong to another century. Your crew ignores the pleading woman and leave to spend the night in the ship, their dreams filled with fantasies of glittering jewels and untold fortunes. When they depart at dawn, there is a longing in their eyes.
Wood Keeper

The indigenous village is filled with food but deserted. After a smooth beaching on the shore, the crew enters the camp of wooden huts: there they find numerous fruits arranged in neat and symmetric piles, and their dried-meat regimen make them eye the fresh food with envy. Not a single villager is in sight.
Try to guess the meaning of the food's peculiar arrangement

The patterns of the offerings converge to a hut. The crew follows the lines of fruits to the biggest hut, where they find a massive statue of wood lying in the dust. Its weathered edges must have seen many generations.
Address the statue for lack of another representative

The praying crew is rewarded with a new path. Several sailors bow down to the statue, in a awkward but respectful manner. The only man able to look directly at the wooden figure notices that the hut's panels behind the statue, which he could have sworn were a solid wall, are not fully closed. Their illusory arrangement cleverly hid a path leading into the woods.
Piece together the clues to understand the village's ritual

Your anthropologist retraces the exact steps of the ritual. To appease their god, probably after the wooden statue fell, the villagers staged a path, probably with the fruits, to lead the god to a prize befitting its anger, probably in this dead trunk right behind the hut. The expert plunges her hand in the bark and retrieves an amulet of woven leaves and fruits. The crew takes it upon itself to make amulet and offerings disappear, confirming that the spirits are appeased.
Explore the woods surrounding the hut

The crew's careful exploration lands a wondrous find. In the trunk of a tree standing right behind the hut, they find an intricate amulet made of vines and fruits which glistens like a jewel. Marveling at their lucky discovery and entering endless debates to guess the meaning of what they saw, they help themselves to the fresh fruits and leave the village.

Nothing of interest is found. The sailors enjoy the beautiful flora, wondering what secrets could hide behind the village's strange appearance. They cannot help but think they have missed something and leave with some of the fresh fruits as a consolation prize.
Reject the invitation and leave

They will have none of this mystical nonsense. The crew hurries away from the wooden figure and focuses on picking a good amount of food before heading back onboard. They know where their priorities are and ignore the unanswered questions that linger among them.

The statue doesn't react to any prayer. A sailor, cross necklace in hand, approaches the wooden figure and mumbles. A salute. An improvised prayer. After a long and unnerving silence, he turns to his mates and confirms that the statue is not answering. Several men utter nervous laughs.
Lift the statue back up

The statue is successfully pulled back up. It is even more impressive in its original position and dominates the room. Sunrays pierce through the hut's roof and fall on the statue, highlighting its uncanny shape and smearing its shadow on the back entrance of the hut.

The statue doesn't budge. As many men as hands can fit on the wooden figure surround the statue and attempt to lift it, to no avail. A sailor wonders if the thing wasn't carved from a standing tree with roots still holding it in place.
Leave this cursed place

They will have none of this mystical nonsense. The crew hurries away from the wooden figure and focuses on picking a good amount of food before heading back onboard. They know where their priorities are and ignore the unanswered questions that linger among them.

The crew shows little respect towards the offerings. The sailors turn over and forage through the piles of fruits, looking for hints of logic in the strange setup. When the villagers appear, drawn by the noise, they are baffled by the mess and immediately draw spears.
Draw swords and brace for the assault

The crew acts as a well-oiled and heartless machine. Years of military training and fighting together make the villagers' assault look puny in comparison, and the attackers are repelled and slaughtered - less than a handful manages to escape. The sailors collect what fruit hasn't been squashed during the fight, and leave without a second thought.

It's a rout. The crew ruins its formation when the villagers attack, and men scatter in all directions save for a line of headstrong sailors. They manage to repel the attackers and pay their unpredictable success with their lives. When those who fled climb back aboard the ship, they carry stolen supplies and the bodies of their fallen protectors.
Do not attack and attempt an apology

The sailors manage to communicate through signs and gesticulations. Two men put in extra effort to mime their hunger and delight at the sight of the fruit piles, rubbing their bellies and humming eating sounds. The villagers answer in a perfectly intelligible language and their laughter follows the crew as it leaves for the ship, supplies in hand.

The crew raises their hands and withdraws. A village elder drops the tip of his spear to the ground and the warriors around him do the same. They do not blink as they survey the crew's retreat. Slowly, carefully, without abrupt movement, the sailors walk backward, out of the village, and into the ship.

Few sailors manage to keep it together. The most resolute raise their hands before the armed villagers, who in turn raise their spears and hoot. The crew breaks in response, groups of terrified men fleeing in all directions and getting skewered by the villagers' lances. Those who did not run are spared and sent back to the ship.

What is happening here is not of God's realm. The crew progresses through the village, too obsessed with the hypnotic patterns of offerings to see the spears coming. Villagers pour from the surrounding woods, hooting and screaming and assailing, and the sailors flee back to the ship in a frenzied panic. They leave before all could it back onboard.
Send a party to look for the missing villagers

A watchful lookout spots the villagers before they attack. The crew is warned and the men have more than enough time to get ready to welcome their armed hosts: they prey onto them and not a single sailor is lost. The villagers who surrender are left alive and the crew accepts several supplies against their magnanimity.
The villagers are found as they attack. A lookout spots the attackers as they run towards the village, and he barely has the time to warn the crew before the warriors dive onto them.

The villagers find the sailors before they are found. As the extended absence of the lookouts starts to worry the crew, ballots of canvas roll from the woods: presents containing the heads of the missing men. Hooting sounds emerge from the trees and rise in power as the men run away in terror before their invisible assailants.
Take the food quickly and leave with it

The crew's carelessness allows the attack. As soon as one of the sailors touches the fruits, a hooting shout resonates around the village and men and women dressed in sticks, creepers and vines appear around the crew. Arrows and spears rain on the sailors who scatter in a panic and flee to the ship, empty-handed and badly wounded.
Apostasy

Little cohabitation can be found among believers and apostates. To ensure the diversity of your crew's skills, your sailors were recruited regardless of their origins or beliefs, and your lieutenants now wonder if this was a mistake. After weeks of lasting rainstorms, the most devout sailors raise their voice: this constant punishment is a sign of the divine, testifying to His obvious displeasure in the heresy onboard. Zealots speak of riot.
Consult the Norse Sagas on the matter

The Old Norse has much wisdom to share.
“Men brave and generous live the best lives, seldom will they sorrow; then there are fools, afraid of everything, who grumble instead of giving.”
Snorri's Edda is a gentle but firm reminder to your sailors that their grievances are shallow and foolish. No agreement is voiced that night, but all know that an understanding is born.
Consult The Odyssey on the matter

The Odyssey's wisdom seeps into your sailors' souls.
"For a friend with an understanding heart is worth no less than a brother."
Gathered around the first mate for an improvised reading session, the sailors can't ignore how the tale of friendship reminds them of their own adventures, of their own mistakes, of their own companions. Difference in faith is a detail. Their unity is what prevails.
Consult The Illiad on the matter

Mythical tales give a lesson to your crew.
"Come then, let us give each other glorious presents, so that any of the Achaians or Trojans may say of us: 'These two fought each other in heart-consuming hate, then joined with each other in close friendship.'"
Hector's speech reminds your sailors of the values that bond them in this expedition: thrill, friendship, discovery, not anger nor fratricide over different beliefs. They sheepishly make up.
Consult Skaldic poetry on the matter

The epic poem puts your crew's petty fights in perspective.
"The battle continued from day to day; and all they who fell, and all the swords that lay on the field of battle, and all the shields, became stone."
The crew itself is petrified as it hangs onto the first mate's every word while he progresses through the poems of the Skáldskaparmál. The tale transports them to a time where pride had a greater value than faith, and their anger goes out.
Consult an ancient romance on the matter

Your sailors bond in their love of a great tale.
“For love will cure him that is sick, and rouse him that is in dumps; one that has loved, it will remember of it; one that has not, it will instruct."
The first mate closes his novel, leaving the crew to ponder over the fate of Daphnis and Chloe. The sailors, moved by their love, find themselves wiping tears over the story. The shared emotion gives them a common ground during which they can pretend their differences do not exist.
Consult the Egyptian tales on the matter

There's a mystifying wisdom in the Egyptian Book of the Dead.
Although no exact quote can be extracted from the detailed drawings, the translator's work in dissecting the Ptolemaic manuscript manages to build texts akin to the original meaning. Your sailors' trivial quarrels reveal their narrow-minded nature as the first mate unravels tales of fratricide and weighed souls. The tensions loosen as much as they can.
Convince the apostates to come back to the light

There is relief in promised forgiveness.
"For the Lord your God is gracious and compassionate. He will not turn his face from you if you return to him."
The priest's words are filled with his own altruism and make the promise ring true. The crew agrees, albeit awkwardly, to put aside their differences and engage in a calm exchange over their beliefs - the anger is quelled, but the heresy remains.

Your priest's ideals are far from peaceful.
"If your friend who is as your own soul entices you secretly, saying, 'Let us go and serve other gods,' your hand shall be first against him to put him to death!"
The menace embodies what the apostates criticise: a blind upholding of beliefs at the cost of your own humanity. The zealous priest is found hanged the next day - a warning to all who would chastise one's faith or lack of it.
Convince the zealots into accepting their differences

Your diplomat finds the right words.
"God is a circle whose center is everywhere and circumference nowhere."
The quote is surprising coming from the woman of law, who manages to put aside her own beliefs to show respect for the zealots' faith. The crew listens intently and all agree that the expedition might be the occasion to discover and appreciate the beliefs of others, despite a sustained atmosphere of skepticism.

The diplomat finds no common ground with the zealots.
"When it is a question of money, everyone is of the same religion!"
The argument is as wrong as it is insulting. Does the man not think that sailors embarked on the expedition for more than their pay? His lack of respect rouses the anger of the zealots, drawing the attention away from the apostates. Nothing more than a shift in the target of their hatred.
Love Island

A matter of the heart. The crew have been enjoying some island hospitality, but many are now refusing to leave. They have fallen in love with the sons and daughters of the local king. Perhaps he can be convinced to allow them to come with you? You can attempt to come to an arrangement, or else wait for him to consult his copper oracle.
Offer a wedding gift

The king is not only surprised, but moved to tears by the romantic composers he hears via the gramophone. He insists on a grand banquet to celebrate the union of his children and your crew. Both traditional music and a few cranks of the new-fangled gramophone accompany the beautiful ceremony, and then its bon voyage!
Convince the king your crew's affection is genuine

The king is delighted to see his children wed. Delicate understanding of local custom and a smattering of their language allow a message of true love to be conveyed. The king evidently thinks his children in good hands. Feasting, and to the amusement of all, terrible dancing, follows. For his departing children, it shall be the longest, most fascinating honeymoon.

Something is lost in translation. Yet the king smiles benignly, as if your crew still have a chance to prove themselves. 'He suggests a great hunt,' says your diplomat, 'or else we may await arcane judgment.' His eyes flick to a copper oracle on a dais.
Capture the king a prize animal

The hunt goes quite well. Beautiful boars inhabit the woods, and though tricky to catch, are little trouble for your experts. Though the king will still not allow you to leave with his children, the feast of boar brings everyone together in the moment. The lovers understand this moment is all they have, and the next morning there is an acceptance that it is time to part ways.

The hunt is not perfect. The crew show courage in pursuit of a tiger, which draws the king's admiration. Sadly, they cannot catch it, which leaves the king wondering if your men will be able to provide once married. Thus, he decides not to let his children leave. Some of your crew remain committed to staying behind, and it is with regret you must continue without them.

Your naive hunters fail the test. Forest deer are everywhere, and hunting them hardly seems a challenge. Had your so-named 'hunters' any respect for nature, they'd have realised the sacred deer were not what the king was after. Instead they gather them up greedily. The king makes it perfectly clear your expedition must move on. With heavy hearts, the sailors return to the ship.
Face the verdict of the copper oracle

The oracle predicts a reassuring fate for all. Those who wish to remain for love will live fulfilling lives, but the same shall be true for those still committed to your expedition. All parties feel a sense of peace. Your voyage shall continue without any resentment towards those it leaves behind.

The copper oracle is disappointingly undecided. The king cannot, in good faith, allow his children to leave to an uncertain destiny. His ultimatum is that your crew become part of his extensive family or else they must leave alone. Though understandable, it is nevertheless regrettable when some decide to stay behind.

The copper oracle predicts that your souls cannot be saved. With your crew rotten to the core, the king makes it clear there can be no union with his children, and that you are no longer welcome. Heart-broken and bearing the burden of sin, the crew return to the triviality of duty.

The awkward gestures and diagrams in the sand prove highly offensive to the king and his people. Sensing outrage, the crew back away towards the ship. The angry locals fire arrows at their former amours. Fittingly, one is struck in the heart, and bleeds out into the brine. The rest return lovelorn, to their dreary maps and compasses.
Await the verdict of the copper oracle

The copper oracle sees only purity in your crew's hearts. It predicts a bounteous future for the king's children, and so with tearful pride, he gives the couples his blessing. The traditional ceremony is both spiritually uplifting and wholesome.

The copper oracle reveals a little doubt in your crew's hearts. The king interprets that his children will only be happy if they remain on the island., and that some of your sailors are not in love, but merely infatuated. Still, you must lose the fine crew who have formed genuine bonds.

The copper oracle reveals great doubt in your crew's hearts. The king does not for a minute believe that your inconstant crew are as deep in love as they claim. If they cannot demonstrate otherwise, it might be better if your people left.
Try to convince the king your crew is worthy

Careful diplomacy has him thinking twice. Perhaps there is a way for the crew to prove themselves. A lean champion steps forward. Fighting him may impress the king, or else you can try and outhunt him.
Propose a contest of champions

You have your champions. One-by-one the suitors fight the king's champion. Those who prevail, it turns out, are permitted to take their lovers to sea. Some fail, but can at least drown their sorrows during the farewell celebration that follows.

It is not a pleasant sight for the faint of heart. Your best champion is put forward, and subsequently knocked about the head for the entirety of the contest. At the end a cloth is needed to conceal the disfigured face. The king expresses his condolences for your loss, but all is fair in love and war.
Propose a hunting competition

It is close but the king's champion is outfoxed. By sundown your best hunter has claimed six boars to their five. The king will still not allow you to leave with his children, but the feast of boar brings everyone together in one moment. The lovers understand a moment is all they have, and the next morning there is an acceptance that it is time to part ways.

Lacking the skill, your hunters try to cheat. Without knowledge of the island's fauna, they decide to follow the king's hunters in the hope of poaching the animal they are tracking. But they are led a merry dance. Three days pass, and your champion is missing presumed dead. The crew have no choice but to depart, tail between their legs.

The king is offended by your insolence. Without a word he boards a boat and heads out to sea. Some foolishly follow, believing he can be reasoned with, but they have even less knowledge of local boats than local customs. Their bodies will be dredged from the reef as your tactless expedition struggles on.
Order the crew to leave at once

Paradise lost! The expedition may be back underway, but the mood is abject as the beautiful island becomes but painful memory. Too painful for one, who is discovered dead, it is said, by way of a broken heart.

The copper oracle proclaims your crew's hearts sinful and wicked. Arm-in-arm with their new-found amours, the sailors await some happy answer. But the moment the king's arm is raised, daggers unsheathe, plunging into the hearts of the would-be lovers. Speechless and unharmed, the rest are free to leave the island, pondering the grave cost of faithlessness.
Leave without the crew who've fallen in love

It is a significant blow. Any happiness the crew might feel at their comrades finding love is consumed by feelings of resentment. How could they have been so selfish? The expedition goes on, but those who are still a part must take on twice as much work.
Temple of the Monkey God

With water supplies so low, the sight of an island waterfall elicits a mighty cheer from the crew. But up close, high temple walls adorned with monkeys shield access to the water, and the temple entrance is obstructed by a crowd of devotees, deep in ritual.
Have [AssetData([ExpeditionEventRequirement]) Text] shed light on the meaning of the ritual

'Nothing to fear from this ritual,' beams the anthropologist, having consulted a bound volume entitled 'Creed of the Monkey God'. 'If I am correct, the devotees gather to disperse the malefic spirit of envy. It would be excellent form for us to join in.' At which remark, the crew begin to look a little hesitant.
Join the ritual

Sure enough, the ritual unfolds into a jolly dance. With the shaking of rainsticks, and gentle swaying must come broad smiles, for this is how the monkey himself defeated the spirit of envy. A feast of grouse and soursop follows, and [AssetData([ExpeditionEventRequirement]) Text] is presented a monkey-tooth amulet as a gift. Next morning, fresh water is collected from the waterfall and having waved goodbye, the happy crew set sail.
Just ask to get some water

[AssetData([ExpeditionEventRequirement]) Text] negotiates the much needed-water, through a lengthy exchange of sound and gesture, not all of which the crew can be certain is relevant. Having collected the water, the crew are content to leave the unanswered mysteries of the Temple of the Monkey God behind them.
Have the first mate convince the devotees to let you through

The first mate does enough to persuade the locals - with flamboyant intimations of the hands - that the crew should be allowed to pass. Once water has been collected from the waterfall, the crew are able to put the adventure behind them.

The first mate cannot make himself understood, despite employing the most outlandish gestures. The constant waving of the hands and legs unsettles the local people and there is suddenly an air of tension.
Have your men threaten them

The men seem slightly uneasy. Still they charge, and the locals do disperse, clearing the way to the waterfall. But long after the water is refilled, and the ship has sailed, the crew have nightmares in which vengeful monkeys bedevil them for defiling their sacred temple.

Before the sorry men can ready their weapons the devotees have attacked, and yet more rush from the undergrowth. The party desperately dashes for the ship, but several are skewered in a rain of javelins, each hilted with the howling visage of the Monkey God.
Stay calm, and offer them a deal instead
The locals look expectant.
Deal
The local people are spellbound by your offer. They invite you enthusiastically to join their ritual.
Join the ritual

The ritual unfolds into a jolly dance. With the shaking of rainsticks, and gentle swaying must come broad smiles, for this is how the temple's monkey god defeated the spirit of envy. A feast of grouse and soursop follows, and as a celebration of trade and friendship, a monkey-tooth amulet is given the men as a gift. Next morning, fresh water is collected from the waterfall and having waved goodbye, the happy crew set sail.
Just ask to get some water

Water goes without saying, seems to be the message from the enterprising devotees, who aren't offended the crew won't participate, but seem now to want to resume their ritual. The crew return to the ship, leaving the unanswered mysteries of the Temple of the Monkey God behind them.
No Deal

The locals are at first interested, but the foremost of them, clad in monkey skins and wearing a linen monkey mask begins scolding his peers, violently knocking offers from their hands with a monkey-pommelled stick. All parties are now just as agitated as before.
Have your men threaten them

The men seem slightly uneasy. Still they charge, and the monkey-mask and his devotees do disperse, clearing the way to the waterfall. But after the water is refilled, and the ship sailed, one of the crew reports nightmares in which vengeful monkeys bedevil him for defiling the sacred temple.

Before the sorry men can ready their weapons monkey-mask has led an attack, and yet more devotees rush from the undergrowth. The men desperately dash for the ship, but several are skewered in a rain of javelins, each hilted with the howling visage of the Monkey God.
Have your men retreat to the ship

Your crew run fearfully from the temple where the devotees stand so firm. The monkey-masked one is heard uttering hard and undecipherable words that many of the crew later become convinced is a curse dooming the expedition.
Offer the devotees some goods in order to pass
Avoid the temple and find another route to the waterfall

The men succeed in finding an alternative route to the waterfall that is also satisfyingly swift. All are happy that they have managed to refill the water so efficiently, and without having to disturb the ritual at the monkey temple.
Your crew tries to find a different way, but it would seem the only option is to reach the high precipice from which the water cascades. The jungle is very dense, and there isn't a clear route up.
Search for a route to the waterfall source

After some scrabbling amid bristly vegetation, the tired crew finally get up to the water source and fill the barrels. The journey back down with the heavy burden is equally exhausting, and scarcely feels worth it.

The men lose their way terribly, becoming separated as they try to prove themselves in the ascent. A dreadful thud sends a squawk of birds from the trees - it is one of the crew, impaled upon a monkey-pommelled javelin. The rest flee for the ship, but few will make it that far.
Give up and return to the ship
'What a waste of all our time' bellows a vexed sailor, and he is not the only one. The word failure is becoming synonymous with this expedition.
Avoid the island altogether and return to the ship
The crew troop sourly back to the ship, disgruntled at being so near, yet so far from this much-needed water source.
Mysterious Artefacts

The discovery of several strange artefacts aboard spooks the crew. Tied to the rigging, bunks, boards, and even atop the captain's desk. A warning, a threat? And who put them there? Since the nearby island is uninhabited, it is sensible only to think the perpetrator must be aboard. The crew must know or have seen something last night!
Ask the anthropologist

'For good luck,' remarks the anthropologist, inspecting the spherical red dolls, 'for the setting of goals, and perseverance in achieving them. Some people or spirit of this place believe they can help us home.' At this, your crew are beguiled.
Ask the crew who did this

Your crew are beginning to bond. Someone comes forward, not having expected to cause such a bother. 'They're for me old mum,' he sighs, 'birds - that one's a little robin. Made 'em together when she was ill. Now she's gone...I...' The others are quick to put an arm round his shoulder; they're all in this together.

No one has anything to offer but the priest. It is his belief that some unholy chapter has opened. The next morning, more of the eerie things have appeared. 'Cleanse the idols in holy fire!' he shrieks. 'Nonsense,' says a soldier. "Set guards within, and we shall have this rat."
Side with the priest and prepare a holy fire

The priest gloats over his success. With a maniacal grin, he sets the mound of idols alight. The fire consumes rapidly, shifting vermillion to viridian. Some say they hear the wood scream as it goes. 'Expurgation is God's work, and I am chosen.'

The fire is chaotic, and the buckets of water seem not to extinguish, but provoke. The flame leaps to the priest's cassock like spring-heeled jack, and as it sweeps up his back, he is heard to utter his last words, 'forgive me father, for I have sinned.'
Keep guard and capture the perpetrator

The teenagers are remorseful. 'It was a jape, a piece o' trickery sirs, we regret t'were not received so.' The crew are forgiving - the youths merely wished to contain their homesickness - and call for just fifty strokes of the birch per bottom.

That night, dire musket-shot is heard. A dead boy on deck, local. A second is seen diving to blue. Next morning a rhythm comes from an armada of river boats, armed with guns. There island is inhabited, and they know what you have done.
Engage in battle.

One warning salvo is enough. The river boats cluster and slow. Though they lower their weapons and allow you to leave, the anger that your crime goes unpunished couldn't be more marked in their faces.

Your ship is a sitting duck. Your crew cannot man stations fast enough to fire or manoeuvre. Enemy boats surround your ship, before scaling its sides. The blood shed on both sides will stain this ship and expedition forever.
Leave immediately.
Once your ship is underway she is free. Nevertheless your adversaries are excellent shots, and do damage to the sails and aft. The crew will have to make repairs in the days that follow.

A traumatic escape. In the hurry to leave, your ship is spun broadside and exposed to gunfire. There are injuries, but none so deep as the sight of the dead boy's accomplice below. He weeps, and clutches one of the idols - a good luck charm.

The sun is solemn that morning. The bodies of the dead guards are borne to the hold for burial, but not here, upon this cursed rock. Who killed them none know but the sinister effigies. The expedition fumbles on.

A destructive episode. No one has information, or perhaps they withhold it. Consensus tends towards the latter. Someone wants this expedition to fail, and these effigies are a threat. Paranoia festers. At the next port, a large part of the crew opts to quit.
Throw them overboard and move on.
Chilling. As instructed, the crew collect the dolls and throw them overboard. But relief lasts only until the following morning, when the dolls are found returned, placed exactly as they had been.
The Mutiny

Clear skies, calm seas, and mutiny brewing among your sailors. The strain of the expedition, the rationing of supplies, the though of danger and the constant, unnerving lack of recognition: it doesn't take much to push the crew over the brink between obedience and its opposite. They unite behind the charisma of their chaplain and drift away from the authority of the first lieutenant.
Have the lieutenant meet the unofficial leader

The two men reach an understanding. The chaplain's demands are understandable, and the first lieutenant's limits are logical. Both agree on working to reach a better balance of power and supply repartition within the crew, and they leave satisfied with the encounter. A fair outcome for everyone.

The discussion reaches an end, somehow. The first mate doesn't listen to the chaplain and the chaplain doesn't hear the first mate. Their to-ing and fro-ing is exasperating even to their own allies. After an endless debate over meaningless details, the two men seem to reach an agreement and shake on it, ending the hostilities. In truth, the established innovations are nothing more than old measures with new faces: novelty, not change.

There is no trust to be found in the rebel's hearts. The chaplain refuses to meet your first lieutenant on the deck and invites him to join him in his own quarters instead: in short, in hostile territory.
Negotiate with the chaplain in his quarters

The lieutenant manages to reason with the chaplain. The officer comes to the ringleaders' quarters unarmed, and stands his ground while surrounded by nothing but hostile faces. He call to the faith of the chaplain and argues for a slow if deep change in the ship's line of command, offering his own position to the chaplain as long as he his kept as a close advisor. His stepping down is discouraging for the loyalists, but it was the only available option at this point.

The meeting goes nowhere. With each new compromise offered by the first lieutenant the chaplain adds an additional request, growing more and more assured of his dominance in the current stalemate. The officer leaves with a list of impossible demands and the ringleader's followers stop working altogether. The ship comes to a stop, waiting for a decision to be made.
Be subtle, send the chaplain poisoned wine

A swift and efficient assassination. Convinced of his advantage in the current situation, the chaplain gracefully accepts the first lieutenant's wine. The poison does not act immediately, but its effect is unequivocal: at dawn, the chaplain is bent over his desk, wide-eyed and grey as dust. No sailor dares to mention the reason for his death. Their caution enforces discipline, fear of their officers, and a general distrust of alcohol.

The poison is obvious. The wine reeks, its smell so deadly and its color so murky it might as well have a skull and bones drawn on its label. The chaplain forces the lieutenant's envoy to drink the whole mixture. As the poor girl quivers and coughs blood and bile, the ringleader and his followers leave their quarters - by the time the envoy is dead, they are standing before the first lieutenant's cabin, armed and set on killing.
In a final attempt at peaceful resolution, offer a bribe
This will be costly.
Okay

The bribe is enough, but its price goes beyond monetary value. The chaplain's despise for the first lieutenant spreads to the crew as they learn of the murder attempt, and the mob of sailors lock their officers in their cabins to stay there until the end of the trip. That they were not killed is the only victory the officers can enjoy.
Cancel

True anger can only be quelled with bribes of blood. The chaplain ignores the first lieutenant's plea. The man of faith pulls a rosary from his wrist, gestures for his men to act, and prays. With each bead which passes under his fingers a rebel plants his sword into the lieutenant, and as the officer screams so does the chaplain chants, louder and louder, until the prayer stops. When they leave the cabin, a new and mad order is established on the ship.
There is no choice but to confront them

Reinforcements come running at the lieutenant's call. The chaplain and his followers are surrounded and swiftly defeated, their strength no match for the loyalists' military training and devotion to their officers. Order is reinstated, the loyalists turned into a militia which reigns over the other sailors and suppresses any attempt at questioning the working conditions and power dynamics on the ship.

The loyalists are less prepared, less convinced, and more brittle. The rebels break them, destroying what few sailors still tried to uphold discipline on the ship. The chaplain has the survivors attached to the mainmast and forced to drink poison, letting their corpses rot where they stand - a display which warns all sailors against condemning his actions. The trip continues under the rule of the chaplain, with the crew convinced that they just replaced a tyrant with another.
Be clear, arrest the chaplain for high treason

The man of faith is captured and executed. The loyalists storm the chaplain's quarters and seize him before his followers can react - men used to fight with words can do little in the face of physical oppression. The chaplain is judged on the deck for all to see and hear, accused of high treason, then hanged on the mainmast and left to rot for a week. Fear keeps the sailors in check for the rest of the trip.

The arrest is a bloodbath. If the loyalists had had an advantage in discipline or numbers, the arrest could have been quick. However, the whole crew enters the melee, sailors hitting each other blindly, unsure which side they're attacking and which they belong to. The chaplain is dragged across the deck and hanged without trial: a display of gratuitous violence which brings the sailors back to their senses. The body of the man of faith oscillates in the wind, shredded and limp, mirroring the crew.
Be ambiguous, ignore the chaplain's demands

Inaction is not what the sailors hoped for. Both loyalists and rebels are dismayed by the absence of decision and restlessness spreads through the crew until the tension finally explodes: the first lieutenant is found dead in his quarters. The defiant act is not punished and most sailors interpret it as yet another sign of weakness, while others argue that the murder was judgment in and of itself.

The discussion is one-sided and disastrous. The first lieutenant barges in the chaplain's quarters and belches a series of commands, menacing the ringleader and his men of flogging, hanging, marooning and flogging again. The loyalists feel ashamed of following such a disrespectful idiot. Under the cover of the night, when the chaplain and his followers steal a long boat to desert the unbearable rule of the officers, many sailors follow. Less than half of the original crew remains.
That's enough disobedience, arrest the chaplain

The loyalists' strength dwindles when facing friends. Loyalists and troublemakers collide in a short and feeble brawl, each side unable to give up or to kill their former crewmates. Shots willingly miss, slashes willingly fumble, punches willingly go limp. The fight goes out without a clear victor, and the rest of the trip is spent with both side wary of each other.

The loyalists are too weak. The conflict erupts into an exchange of slurs, then blows, then gunshots. Men and women frantically try to kill sailors who were good friends and both first lieutenant and chaplain are no exceptions: the ring leader unexpectedly draw a sword and both men impale each other, their deaths signaling the end of the senseless fight. The crew collects its thoughts to mourn the man of Church for the efforts he put in for them.
Offer a rise to the chaplain
The chaplain looks expectantly.
Okay

A pragmatic solution. The amount offered to the chaplain to buy his obedience is enough for the man of faith to ignore the incongruity of the monetary negotiations. With the roots of their problem still present the crew remains unruly, but the bought leader makes sure to maintain their anger at the lowest levels.
Cancel

The offer does not match the chaplain's expectations. If his calmness is to be bought, the price should be enough for him to share with all the sailors he roused. The offended man of faith retreats to his quarters without a word.
Make an example out of the ring leader

The budding mutiny is easily crushed. The first lieutenant and two loyalists are all it takes to seize the chaplain and drag him to judgement: the man is condemned to be marooned on the next deserted island they find, and left to die at will or live in solitude. The swift arrest and punishment impresses the rest of the crew and renews their respect for their officers.

The loyalists' strength dwindles when facing friends. Loyalists and troublemakers collide in a short and feeble brawl, each side unable to give up or to kill their former crewmates. Shots willingly miss, slashes willingly fumble, punches willingly go limp. The fight goes out without a clear victor, and the rest of the trip is spent with both side wary of each other.

The loyalists are too weak. The conflict erupts into an exchange of slurs, then blows, then gunshots. Men and women frantically try to kill sailors who were good friends and both first lieutenant and chaplain are no exceptions: the man of faith unexpectedly draws a sword and both men impale each other, their deaths signaling the end of the senseless fight. The crew collects its thoughts to mourn the chaplain and the price he paid for them.
Ignore the discontent and let it wane

Inaction is not what the sailors hoped for. Both loyalists and rebels are dismayed by the absence of decision and restlessness spreads through the crew until the tension finally explodes: the first lieutenant is found dead in his quarters. The defiant act is not punished and most sailors interpret it as yet another sign of weakness, while others argue that the murder was judgment in and of itself.
The Amazons

The splendid warriors are all women. Exploring the deserted coastal settlement was a nice opportunity for looting, but it seems your crew wasn't the only one to get this idea. As they push the village's rundown barricade, they happen upon a group of warriors who immediately assume a defensive formation in a motion almost too perfect to be human. There's not a single man among them.
Let a woman do the talking

The warriors greatly enjoy your specialist's company. Glad to see a fellow woman act as a presence of power, the fighters invite your crew to share the bounty of their raiding: despite the difference in tongue and civilization, your sailors enjoy a feast of exotic game and liquor and spend the night improvising songs and dances with the women.
Present your peaceful intentions

Your diplomat dispels the barrier of language. Mimicking the sailors' trip through the seas and showing the women their ship, maps and supplies, the diplomat manages to have them understand the goals of your crew. The warriors eagerly observe your charts and point out what areas your ship should investigate next - their excitement suggesting their own love of discovery. Crew and women part with the conviction of having met like-minded explorers.

Groveling is not respect. Your diplomat treats the women like savages, kneeling before them and uttering oooh and aaah sounds which are seen as insulting even by the crew. One of the female warriors steps forward and plants a lance in his thigh.
Respond to their violence in kind
