Your guns provide an underhanded upper hand. While the warriors fight with lances and short war hammers, your sailors draw their pistols and fire them at will. The women draw back, dragging their wounded and dead away, while your crew savor the bitter victory. How would they have fared without the guns?

Small arms, huge defeat. The sailors fire their pistols at the women in a clumsy and disorganized manner, which cannot hold against the warriors' discipline and flawless coordination. Walking on the corpses of their own kin, the women pierce through your ranks and slaughter them. They spare what few explorers were women and let them run back to the ship.
Appease them with gifts
The women look interested but cautious.
Confirm

The exotic supplies intrigue the warriors. Curiosity replaces their anger and seeing how fascinated they are by the crew's maps, the sailors guess that the women might share their taste for exploration. Sadly, it is too late to earn the warriors' trust and they leave with your presents in silence.
Cancel

A waste of time. The warriors barely have the time to examine your supplies that an officer barks an order to pull the crates back into the ship, leaving the women baffled and offended. The officer heads flies and the warriors cleave through your sailors until they reach your cargo. They leave with a tall barrel of liquor and disappear from the scene of carnage.
Bow before the goddesses

Your crew's deference pleases the warriors. Surprised by the sailors bowing before them in respect, the women giggle and lower their guard. They tap the explorers' chins with the tip of their lances, inviting them to drop their hunching position for a proper face-to-face. Although they do not share a language, they manage to communicate through their love of meat and drink, and the feast lasts deep into the night.

Can these men show real respect? Your sailors cannot translate their admiration in their acts. They crawl to the women and hold their hands, letting their sweat soil the soft skin and their eyes trail the soft shapes. One of the warrior spits to their face in disgust. The other women imitate her and walk away, whispering among themselves.
Wash this offense in blood

The assault is one-sided. Your sailors draw their guns and shoot the warriors in their backs, taking down the women with ease and ganging up against the remaining ones. Reassured of their fortitude, the men leave the settlement and try to ignore the debasing aspect of this unnecessary bloodshed.

Skill, conviction, discipline: your men lack them all. They draw their guns and fire at the women, who react at once and pounce on their assailants. Short war hammers appear in their hands and end up in skulls. One hit, one kill. Terrified by the warriors' martial ability, the survivors abandon the fight and run back to the ship.
Ignore the humiliation and let them leave

The sailors feel humiliated. They let the warriors leave and console themselves as they can by looting the remains of the settlement, but the women have left no stone unturned. Empty-handed and disgraced, they go back to the ship.
The Runaway

The local authorities are looking for the refugee you have taken in. A man in rags offers you his services in a harbour, arguing that he'd do any odd job for food and a chance at joining your crew. Unlike other temporary hires, he grows onto your sailors, filling in wherever there is work, catching onto the ship's spirit and disputing debates over the expedition's course. His skills testify to a life beyond that of a common sailor, but your crew respects his secrecy. As your ship leaves the harbour, a patrolling warship stops it: they are looking for a political dissident and the description matches your new recruit.
"We have never seen him."

Your crew presents a coherent lie. Have anyone anywhere seen anybody? They inspect the picture of the runaway, speculate on hiding places, rummage through the cargo while the refugee buries under the supplies, unseen. The pretence of dedication convinces the authorities, who leave after a warm acknowledgement of their efforts. When the harbour is out of sight, the runaway emerges with a grin worth all thanks. A new recruit for your expedition!

Your crew's deceit is silly at best. The lieutenants argue that they just arrived into port and couldn't possibly have had any contact with the population yet, but the warship obviously saw your vessel dock at the harbour. Their suspicions roused, they ask you to lower a footbridge for an inspection of the ship.
Hide the man and allow them onboard

No better places to hide than the ones you know by heart. Your sailors stash the fugitive into the belly of the ship, a bundle of rags buried between crates of supplies and sacks of food. A perfect camouflage. The patrolling guards soon abandon their inspection and let your ship leave after taking note of its name. To avoid future inspections, the runaway chooses to leave at the next island.

The fugitive is more lost than the guards. Your sailors shove him in the lower deck and urge him to hide without any form of guidance or advice. When the patrol guards descend into the ship, they find the runaway rummaging through the crates, still looking for a place to hide. They immediately seize him.
Enough complying already - threaten them to leave or else!

Your threat works despite the situation. The sailors surround the guards in silence, stepping between them and the runaway, forcing the intruders to the upper deck and off the ship. Your vessel leaves before they can call reinforcements and the fugitive is dropped at the first harbour, for fear of retaliation. The separation is hurried and leaves a sour aftertaste. At least, with luck, he'll be safe.

There's no threatening these men. Your sailors try to step between them and the runaway, but the lump of scrawny arms and pouting faces is far from intimidating. They are shoved away and what few sailors try to resist are hauled along with the fugitive and taken to suffer his fate: death by hanging.
Enough errors already - let them take the man

Your crew offers little resistance. They part before the patrol as it advances to seize the runaway. The dissident starts to thank the sailors for their efforts, but a slap shuts him up and he is collared before being dragged away. Your crew never managed to create the safe haven he deserved. They watch the warship disappear along the coast, trying to refrain from imagining the fate of their friend.
Threaten to fire your cannons at their ship

Your firepower is impressive indeed. The sailors line all hatches with cannons and light their fuses in the same movement, aiming the dark mouths at the patrolling warship. The patrol captain hurriedly orders his own crew to hurtle away from the crazy fools. The cannonade salutes their departure. The fugitive is extremely thankful and leave your crew at the next island with a warm goodbye.

An empty threat. Lying about your itinerary was more credible than pretending your ship can muster any form of naval power. Eyeing your sailors as they struggle to deploy and load the cannons, the patrol captain orders his men to get ready to board your ship. Your crew is suspicious enough for him.
They don't board you. You board them!

The assault is abrupt and wicked. For an agonizing moment of hesitation none seems to prevail, until your sailors manage to get the upper hand and slaughter the warship's crew. Your vessel flees the harbour and drops the fugitive at the next safe island, aware they have made enemies out of legal authorities for the sake of one good man.

The fight is routine for your opponents. Your crew boards the warship with nothing more than their confidence, and their sluggish skills crash against the overwhelming discipline of the patrol guards. The runaway stands up to help your sailors, screaming to get the guards' attention, and is instantly shot. His death marks the end of the fight. Your ship is exiled before the crew can mourn their dead.
Let them board the ship and take the man
"Is it a fight you are looking for?"

The patrol cowers away from your ship. Of course they are not looking for a fight, not with a vessel looking as overpowered as yours! It might have been their swift deployment of cannons or the absolute stoicism with which your sailors warned the patrol - either way, your presence and menace is overwhelming. Your ship is free to leave the harbour, its new recruit already toasting to his freedom and the crew gladly following him.

The patrol is not impressed by your ship's armament. Your crew flings slurs at the inspection warship and scatters through the ship, deploying unsteady cannons, bumping against closed hatches and very audibly cursing their lack of ammunitions. Trying to refrain his laughter as his own crew deploys brand new ordnance rifles, the patrol captain asks your sailors to demonstrate how they intend to overpower him.
Demonstrate

It takes one accurate shot to demonstrate power. Giving up on shooting all cannons, your sailors focus on firing the single best shot of their lives. The cannonball flies past the warship's railings and crushes their mainmast, sending wood and metal to rain on the patrol guards and giving your ship the window of time necessary to flee. The fugitive leaves your crew at the next island, grateful but unwilling to aggravate your feud with the local authorities.

Poor decision. Following their display of clumsy preparation, your sailors try to attack using the artillery they were insulting a second before. The cannons rear under their mishandling and fire at the ship itself, piercing hole after hole in the hull and hurling sailors into the sea. The patrol faces no resistance when they come onboard, pluck the fugitive, and leave the devastated vessel.
Surrender

Your crew offers little resistance. They part before the patrol as it advances to seize the runaway. The dissident starts to thank the sailors for their efforts, but a slap shuts him up and he is collared before being dragged away. Your crew never managed to create the safe haven he deserved. They watch the warship disappear along the coast, trying to refrain from imagining the fate of their friend.
"You have never seen us."
The fugitive holds his breath as you prepare the bribe.
Confirm

A smooth operation. The patrol pockets your goods with twisted smiles, your payment surpassing the rewards promised for the capture of the runaway. As they clear the way and your ship passes by them, your new recruit waves to the guards and curtsies before wishing them a great day. Yes, your crew is going to like him.
Cancel

Your offer is far from enough. The patrolling guards must have been promised a great reward for the capture of the fugitive. Taking your attempt as an effort to bribe them and highly suspicious behaviour, they lower footbridges and open cannon hatches, ready to board your ship.
"Here is the man you are looking for."

Your sailors hand over the runaway. The refugee is dejected but keeps his emotions in check, letting the patrolling guards chain him while looking straight at your crew. His look is avoided. The patrol rewards the sailors with bags of supplies, a miserable trade for the life of a good man and the shame of your crew.
The Predator

'A fearsome predator stalks us!' the cabin-boy whispers. Perhaps he is right, for this resupply has not been as uneventful as hoped. Only the first evening moored in this bay, and a man goes missing - tracks up the beach into jungle. Many wonder how work can be expected to continue...
Bait the creature

With the perfect lure placed enticingly in the crook of a tree, there is an inevitability about a capture. Sure enough, yellow eyes pierce the darkness, and a mighty beast pads softly over to the bait. A net is hurriedly cast about it and secured, thus leaving the expedition free to resupply unthreatened.
Send hunters to track it

Your huntmasters are expert, and trace with great care, the soft hollows imprinted by feline paw. Led to a clearing, they correctly judge this to be a lair, where they stand ready with a net. When the cat returns, heaving hot breath, the hunters pounce. With net secure, the expedition is free to resupply unthreatened.

At least one hunter did the right thing, and kept his eyes open while they traced the beast's pawprints. Another was not so wise, and was heard to let out a scream. His comrades were drawn to the spot, and struck the majestic beast down. But not before the damage was done.
Three days pass, and still no word. There is a common feeling something must be done to save those men.
Send a rescue party

It is only something of a relief when the rescue party return. It's bad news... the hunters are dead. The rescue party described the bright and long-maned beast, and how in a tussle, they slayed it. With the bodies of the hunters buried, the expedition is able to resupply in an atmosphere of respectful silence.

'Horror! It's picking us off one by one!' bawls a fearful sailor, for now the rescue party too, have failed to return. There is nothing for the disconsolate remainder of the crew to do, but leave this sorry place behind.
Wait a bit longer
Doubtful prayer brings no news of the lost hunters. The men have nowhere to look for guidance, and there is a burdensome feeling that a decision must be made.

Conviction in the lord is of little use here, it seems. Two days later a hunter, whose leg is mangled, limps back into view. After the necessary amputation, he is heard to groan that the others perished. All must leave this savage place.
Leave the island without them

'We leave them for dead, when they could be right there now waiting for us!' cries a furious old tar. Like so many others, he is disgusted that good men should give their lives for nothing but impatience!
Speak with locals

'Absurd magic, but it works!' say officers sent to the inland village for help. Having described the beast, they were referred to a witch. She encouraged them to ingest live scorpions, one of each colour; yellow, red and black. This they did reluctantly, but found when they confronted the animal, it took flight. All promptly follow the witch's advice, and sure enough, remain undisturbed for the remainder of the resupply.
'Our plight means nothing to the locals,' bemoan the officers sent as diplomats. 'Telling them beasts stalk the jungle, is as like alerting a hatter to the presence of hats on his hatstands.'
'Their deity is desecrated!' urges the officer sent as diplomat. All around the bay, daubed faces appear, bows raised to the expedition camp.
Teach them a lesson
'A hollow victory', say the men. For the locals lie dead, but the jungle beast stalks on.

Odds against them, the men fight as best they can. Fought back onto the sand, they deflect the rain of arrows with whatever they can lay hands on. A relay is able to return precious equipment to the ship and set sail, but not without a number of casualties, of whom some do not make it.

The onslaught is deadly. Few among your crew have the requisite experience to defend themselves, and so the sand reddens with their blood. Of those who make it as far as the expedition ship, a number succumb to the poison-tip arrows. It is a massacre.
Run for the ship!

'Run!' comes the panicked cry. The men drop their work, and tramp desperately through the shallows to the ship. A volley of arrows pierces three, squirting crimson into the clear blue. 'Dead aside, we have lost a great deal more in provisions than we have gained,' laments the quartermaster, as your ship departs that wretched bay.
Lay a trap

The ingenious powers of the craftsmen among your crew have fashioned a pitfall for the beast. There is not long to wait before there is a tinkle on the handbell, and all can gather above the trap to see the monster growling at its bottom. The resupply may now happily proceed, knowing that danger is averted.
The beast is too intelligent to fall for makeshift traps. It is clearly evading the pitfall prepared by those supposed to be the expedition's deftest craftsmen. 'Little more we can do,' they shrug.
Leave the island

'It's a considerable setback,' say senior officers. Fresh water, wood for burning, plants for medicine - it does no good to list what myriad opportunities are missed in bypassing the bay. And all for the sake of fears over one measly wild animal.
A Grizzly Encounter

Bear attack! The party ponder this very real possibility as threatening grunts stop them dead among the firs. Fifty yards ahead, a huge specimen lurches up on two legs like a totem, standing between them and escape. More grunting echoes nearby. The party stay silent, awaiting guidance.
Scare the bears away
Boooooom! The valley shudders with the sweet stench of exploded dynamite. The bears hurry away, leaving the crew thoroughly entertained at the superiority of mankind and the power of invention.
Use hunting knowledge to get the better of the bears

Trust in the expert hunters never feels misplaced, even when they recommend the party break into passionate song. For singing the shanty 'Cheerly-ay-oh' brings the crew together, whilst also dispersing the wary bears deep into the forest.

The hunters lack guile. They have enough to lead the crew on a route silent as a church, but not enough to stop a bear sniffing them out. It's easy to believe from its vacant eyes, that it sees you as a potentially delicious kind of threat.
Attack the bear

The bear's face proves a good target. Ducking the terrifying whooshes of its paws, someone manages to prime their pistol and shoot it through the eye. The bear drops dead. No-one feels particularly good about killing it, but the way ahead is now clear.

Adaptation is good when a fight isn't going well. The bear flinches but does not drop after the first round of gunfire. There is no time to reload, before it is upon them with its paws. Knocked down the men are smart enough to play dead. After an hour or so facing the floor, the bears lose interest and leave. The crew are able to lick their wounds, and move on.

It's easy to underestimate mummy bears. As the soldiers fluff the loading of their weapons, the bear nonchalantly grasps one by the wrist, and sinks her jaw into his neck. The others panic and flee with their arms in the air. She pursues a second, striking him dead against a rock. Now she and her cubs can finally be left in peace.
Outmanoeuvre the bear

Sometimes it helps to know your hill contours. The crew carefully fall away, circumventing the bear's position, and keeping their backs to the mountainside. With the higher ground, the bear appears to lose interest. Hearts pumping, the crew hurry to safety.

Stupidly the crew decide to run, and reach a dead-end. The bear pursues at a leisurely speed, yet with no less menace, and the crew are forced to seek refuge in a cave, or else try climbing the trees.
Hide in the cave and pray

Against all anxiety, the Bear doesn't follow. Still, the men in the cave are too afraid to light a fire, or sleep through the night. Shattered and hungry, they emerge the next morning, only to find their sacrifice was wholly unnecessary.

Bears can see terribly well in the dark, and since your crew have stumbled into its house, where its vulnerable infants sleep, it is not very happy. The crew that do manage to break for daylight have clothes ragged and torn, and cannot speak, for it is clear they were the lucky ones.
Climb the trees

The crew climb the trees well enough, but the bear isn't going to make their lives easy. It is a full day and night before it gives up shaking trunks, or climbing halfway up towards the dangling crew. When it finally leaves, the exhausted crew descend, their nerves in shreds.

Bears are awfully good at climbing trees, and as on this occasion, it is not uncommon to see them strike their adversaries from the branches. Its hapless victim plunges from the canopy and lands like a sack of red berries on rocks below. Others injure themselves as the men drop from the trees in a desperate escape.

Call themselves hunters! The tracks thought to lead away from bear territory go instead to a clearing at its heart. The bears at first seem alarmed their picnic is disturbed, until they realise your crew are on the menu. The sound of crunching bone rings in the ears of the few that manage to flee.
Attack the bear blocking the way

The lone bear's haunch is picked out with expert marksmanship. It staggers before bounding off into the woods. Your crew are delighted to return to the safety of the ship, whilst also having done the mighty beast no lasting harm.

The first volley of shots miss, and the bear attacks. A second shot finds its mark, and the wounded bear escapes into the trees, but a man lies dead. His brother cries revenge, and is already off into the woods to hunt the grisly killer.
Track the wounded bear with him

Bittersweet. Your fine tracking skills allow the crew to catch up with the bear and watch it from hiding. It is a she-bear, and is now nuzzling its young cubs. 'That is why she killed him,' says the brother, gone all vitriol. 'Let us leave, and hope my brother's spirit may somehow live on in this place.'

The hot-headed hunt is a success none celebrate. Once found, the bear no longer has strength to defend itself. As the brother drives a stake into its heart, it gives over with a last sad sigh. In that moment a tiny cub pads into the open, crawling weakly under the limp arm of its mother. If only they had understood, the crew could have saved the heartache.

Hunting is impossible with passions running this high. When another man snaps a twig, the vengeful brother attacks him wildly, and the others fail to intervene. The brother's eyes glaze as he slides to the earth, bayonet in his back.
Leave the fool behind

The decision is unpopular. 'Stubborn 'til the end,' say those in the minority. But the greater part have things to say on the subject of dishonour. 'Those brothers loved each other to the end,' remarks one old sailor, 'and what little love did we show for them...'

Out here, bears rule. The wildly inaccurate gunfire serves only to rile the bear into a frenzy, and draw attention to your position. Then a second, larger bear thunders from the undergrowth and mauls a man to death. A few of your piffling soldiery manage to escape with all their limbs attached.
Use Camouflage

The bears have no chance. Indeed, the camouflage is so good, the crew can barely see one another! Thickly daubed in the colours of the forest, the chameleon crew bypass the bears with ease. A story of ingenuity at which their grandchildren shall marvel!

Even the most hardened sailors find the smell unbearable. Not to mention the indignity of covering oneself in bear excrement for longer than is perfectly necessary. Eventually though the bears depart, leaving the reeking crew free to have a much-needed wash.

Dressing as pantomime trees is a bad idea, and as the bears attack, the flimsy branches the crew intended to cover their faces prove no more effective in self-defence. The ensuing scene might have made for an impressive spectacle on the stage, though only as the most gruesome of tragedies.
Release the Kraken
A kraken! The rainstorm parts to reveal tentacles wide as a barrel and long as ten men, snaking between the waves. The creature of legends is heading towards the ship at full speed.
Fire a torpedo at the beast

The so-called beast is no match for a torpedo. Firing a torpedo is a first for most of your crew, yet they manage to handle the unusual weaponry with skill. The self-propelled projectile flies underwater and crashes into the kraken with an explosion that shakes the storm itself. One more tale to tell back home!
Kill the monster

If harpoons can kill whales, they can kill monsters. Despite the pounding rain and poor visibility, the sailors manage to load a harpoon and fire it at the kraken: the beast shakes, flails, and disappears into the sea under the triumphant cheers of the crew.

Panicked men try to shoot at the monster. The bullets drop into the water like meaningless pebbles and do no harm to the kraken except rouse its anger. Flailing its tentacles, the creature hits the ship with full force and soon ensnares the boat.
Try to cut the tentacles

The gigantic tentacles are sawed off. Using the engineers' oversized ship saw, the sailors manage to cut through the elastic flesh of the monster. The kraken convulses and lets go of ship, leaving the crew to repair the boat and wipe out what gooey blood was spilled on the deck.

Measly men make no miracles. The sailors assault the tentacles, trying to plant what swords and knives and forks they have at hand into the thick flesh. The suckers stay glued to the deck. The beast shakes and its suckers tremble, extending for a tense second before bouncing back up, taking large parts of the deck with them. Wood and metal rain over the sailors and the kraken leaves them to die.
Try to bombard the kraken

The creature matches your strength for a short while. It grabs the ship and rocks it, shaking several cannons away from their sailors. The remaining artillery is fired without delay and strikes the kraken into submission, sending it back to the depths it came from. The sailors have but light repairs to perform on the cannons.

The power of the beast largely surpasses yours. A glassy eye levels with the deck, reflecting the sailors's silhouettes as they make hurried preparations to shoot the cannons. The cannonballs fly by the kraken and leave it unscathed, allowing it to grapple and tip over the ship with its unsheathed hooks, pouring sailors into its beak. It then disappears from your crew's sight, but not their nightmares.
Outrun the thing

Full steam ahead! Using the full power of your steam ship, the vessel leaps and tears through the waves, leaving the kraken to swirl in its wake. A sailor blows the ship's horn to salute the creature and watches in delight as it plunges back into the ocean.

The wind is ideal for such a maneuver. Your navigators and sailors rush to their posts and work to align ship and storm, fusing the vessel with the elements. The wind carries the ship away from the kraken, and delivers it to a sunny clearing of calm and monsterless waters.

Your crew cannot outmaneuver the storm. They wrestle the wind and rain, their struggle showing in the chaotic movements of the ship. The kraken slips under the vessel and emerges in front of it, stopping any escape attempt by ensnaring the prow in its tentacles.
Teeth of the Mountain

These tracks could belong to maneaters. The crew's reconnaissance report carried intriguing rumours of local threats: abducted men and women, quarries filled with human bones, and a mountain chain too impenetrable to be devoid of valuable finds. Almost as soon as your explorers start their ascension, they spot fresh tracks in the dry leaves.
Follow the tracks

Your sailors follow the tracks without trouble. The trail of footprints runs among the mountain's trees, zigzaging among dead leaves and fallen trunks, disappearing under the steps of your explorers. It leads the sailors deep into the forest, to a clearing where a tiny village is nested. Under the tiled roofs of their Old World homes, the inhabitants are white-skinned and blue-eyed. If they are cannibals, they don't look the part.
Engage a friendly conversation with the inhabitants

Your diplomat realizes that the autochthons speak a similar language. The blue-eyed inhabitants answer in a patois laced with foreign expressions and sounds, but there is no mistaking the origins of their dialect. Pleased by the diplomat's banter, they invite your crew to share a feast of exotic meats and vegetables, and describe the grand adventures of their ancestors to your fascinated crew: tales of exiled war prisoners and their fight to create a new home.

The diplomat mistakes civilized aspect for civilized behaviour. She strides straight into the village, confident in the autochthons' pacifism, and spreads her arms to the nearest woman - a young girl who shrieks upon seeing her and bites the welcoming hand. The alerted villagers surround your diplomat with pitchforks and shovels. They creep on her, poking her with their improvised weapons.
Face the villagers to rescue your diplomat

The crew manages to rescue her. Taking advantage of the villagers' obsession with the intruder, the sailors surround them and attack as one in a flurry of gunshots and slicing swords. Visibly terrified by the pistols and unable to face the military unison of your crew, the autochthons flee and leave the diplomat to be rescued. Wether the encounter could have been solved peacefully, you will never know.

Your crew is overwhelmed. They attempt a clumsy charge, overlooking any assessment of the enemy's strength, and crash against the wall of peasants' weapons. They disband as fast as they engaged the fight and become easy targets for the villagers, who gleefully hunt them and cheer each time a sailor is struck down. The rare survivors are left to ponder what grim fate awaits those who were captured.
Run away without her

Run, run away! Leaving your diplomat to face the villagers alone, the crew flees back to the ship. As they bury into the forest they hear a sudden and hideous scream, which ends as brutally as it erupted. No sailor comment on the voice: they all recognized the diplomat.
Survey the village's activity from a distance

The crew is undetected and detects nothing of interest. Your sailors conceal themselves among the trees and observe the villagers from a distance, too far from their activities to understand the reasons for the inhabitants' busy bustle. They return to the ship without proof nor denial of the rumoured cannibalism.

You call that discreet? The sailors tiptoe around the village, stopping every few feet to comment on which branch they should or shouldn't step on, so focused on their feet they do not even consider how the wind carries their sounds and smells. When they finally raise their heads, an army of pitchforks welcomes them.
Apologise to the villagers for trespassing

Your diplomat manages to be understood. She mumbles a variety of foreign words until the villagers, touched by her efforts, respond. Their language is intelligible, if made of outdated expressions: a testimony to their ancestors, they say, war prisoners sent to die here generations ago. They leave little doubt regarding which country sent them. Your sailors are ushered away before they can inquire about the villagers' past or their dietary habits.

Rather than apologise, your diplomat crawls. She tugs at the villagers' sleeves and shows how unarmed she is, advising your sailors to drop their own weapons in order to display their benevolence. Rather than restraint, the villagers see submission. They take the weaponry and let the sailors escape in exchange for the diplomat - the last your crew sees of her is her figure tied to a towering pole, for a purpose best left unknown.
Strike first!

Where discretion fails, force prevails. Your crew is unfazed by the villagers and springs to action: its sudden and precise attack knocks them down and their resistance drowns under the repeated assaults of the sailors. Your explorers step over the corpses and explore the now deserted village, where they find strings of human bones attached between houses and clicking in the breeze. They have eradicated a terrible menace!

Your sailors are trampled. Their meager military training barely resists in the face of the assault. The crew dissolves and flees into the forest. To their horror, human-sized snares lie on the ground, all metal teeth and blade tongues, and they bite and hook legs in a terribly perfect choreography. This forest was made to hunt humans. About half of the sailors makes it back to the ship, the others fallen prey to the maneating mountain.

The path escapes the explorers, who find themselves surrounded. The crew's untrained eyes cannot catch the details which indicate that the danger does not lie ahead, but behind them. When they finally sense the hostile presence, they turn to discover a vision way below their expectations: instead of savages with pierced skin and belts of human bones, they discover white men and women, their eyes blue and their clothes very civilized.
Avoid the tracks

Avoiding the tracks apparently means getting as lost as possible. Taking care not to cross the path of whoever laid these footprints, the sailors avoid all semblances of roads and bury themselves deep into the mountain's forest. They emerge after three days of aimless wandering, devoured not by the rumoured cannibals but by mosquitoes, ticks and leeches.

Avoiding the tracks apparently means getting as lost as possible. Taking care not to cross the path of whoever laid these footprints, the sailors avoid all semblances of roads and bury themselves deep into the mountain's forest. They emerge after three days of aimless wandering, devoured not by the rumoured cannibals but by mosquitoes, ticks and leeches.
The Mayan Map

Chipped paint and golden ink: this map might lead you to El Dorado. The sailors eagerly whisper and envision new fortunes, seeing the map as the most bona fide lead they've ever had on the glorious golden city. The map is not a rare item: several expedition team have owned and followed it, but all campaigns ended in disaster. Will your crew be the one to prevail against the Mayan map's challenges?
Hire a guide to navigate the jungle
The guide waits for an offer.
Confirm

The guide is used to following the Mayan map. She leads the crew through a path she knows by heart, and your sailors cannot help but wonder about the fate of the previous explorers. Dead, the guide says. She halts as the group comes near a waterfall, its center parted by a carved crag and opening on a cave filled with the echo of dripping water. The map insists you should go inside, but the guide refuses to go any further: death awaits beyond this threshold.
Cancel
Your crew is on its own. The guide scoffs at their refusal to pay her price, and wishes them good luck, teasing them about dangers as numerous as they are implausible. The sailors tense up.
Follow the map without help

The sailors follow the Mayan map through the jungle maze. Tracks of the numerous explorers who came before them render the terrain illegible, but your crew is seasoned in the art of tracking and manage to find what little clues were left intact after the passage of the previous adventurers. Here two intertwined trees match the map. There a majestic waterfall. As they approach the later, they see its waters are parted by a large carved stone: underneath it is the gaping mouth of a cave.
Interpret the carvings on the stone

The true treasure map is carved into the stone! Your anthropologist examines the engraved crag which marks the tunnel's entrance, and understands the passage is a decoy. He combines the Mayan map with the carvings' scattered indications and leads your explorers to the pond at the feet of the waterfall. The sailors dive, bringing back piece after piece of mossy coral, which reveal artifacts when opened. A clever find!
Examine the cave for secret passages

A passage! The crew scrutinizes the cave's walls and are not fooled by the water flowing along them. They push through the liquid curtain and feel no ground behind it - the veil of water hides an exit. They emerge soaked, a cold breeze sticking their clothes to their skin. The wind comes from several tunnels ahead. The Mayan map indicates the correct road, but the tunnel itself states otherwise: it is collapsed and full of debris.
Build a scaffold to clear the rubble of the right path

The path is secured and the reward is worth the effort. The sailors with carpenter skills erect makeshift scaffolding along the sides of the blocked tunnel, progressing inch by inch as the others clear the rubble below. As they push yet another boulder, it falls forward and lets a ray of golden light pierce through. Is this El Dorado? The pyramidal cave beyond doesn't look like a city, but it is indeed filled with precious artifacts.

The architectural exercise is more than your crew can handle. They try to clear the rubble while supporting the tunnel's ceiling with what logs and rocks they can find, but with each new consolidation come new pieces on the brink of falling. As they push yet another boulder, it falls forward and the whole structure follows, collapsing onto itself and burying the road to El Dorado for good.
Find a way through the other tunnels

Your crew triumphs of the labyrinth. Following the cryptic indications of the Mayan map, they navigate through the damp tunnels and their intricate structure, taking care to mark their path onto the map for the travel back. They emerge into a cave shaped like an inverted pyramid, its center adorned with centuries-old frescoes and clay pots protecting ancient offerings. The effort was worth it!

Going forward is easy, going back never is. Unsure whether navigating the alternative tunnels is a good idea, the crew sends groups of two into the passageways. Devoid of the Mayan map and unable to orient themselves in the underground labyrinth, the sailors get lost in its unfathomable depths. Those who make it back are devoured by claustrophobia while those who found treasures pay it with their eternal imprisonment.

They find nothing. The cave is a beautiful place, its walls covered in steady streams which catch the sunlight and its air saturated with the fresh smell of moss, but no other treasures than memories can be discovered here. The crew departs, aware that the Mayan map promised much more than what they found.
Enter the cave and pray for guidance

Their praying guide the explorers through the darkness. As they plead for higher beings to protect them, their voices echo through the cave's wall, indicating a concealed gap in it. They cross the lucky shortcut and arrive in a large grotto pierced by multiple openings. The Mayan map points out the correct path, but time has taken its toll: the tunnel is collapsed.

Are they expecting the cave to self-explore? The crew sits in prayer, hoping their efforts will be rewarded with a divine sign. When the only sound to answer their pleading is the rumbling protest of their hungry stomachs, they agree that the Mayan map was a fake designed for entertainment rather than actual adventure, and they leave the rolled parchment on the ground to be slowly consumed by the mud.

The sailors can't find their bearings - the jungle swallow them. They fall into its pits, get clawed by its beasts, bitten by its swarms, chewed by its venomous bushes and flowers and trees. Every single living thing in the jungle tries to kill them and most succeed. Only three explorers make it back alive, swollen and feverish versions of their previous selves who babble about the Mayan map until the end of the trip.
The risks outweigh the rewards, ignore the map

The map is ignored and the sailors dispirited. Of course, they too understand the risks. Of course, they too see the uncertainty. Of course, but isn't the whole point of expeditions to venture into the uncertain and face unknown risks?
A Fistful of Doubloons

The ship's coffers have been emptied! Your purser knew these new recruits had a wicked air about them. As soon as the ship reached port and the sailors were allowed some rest, the three landsmen merged with the local crowd and disappeared and with them went weeks of pay. The theft was planned in every minute detail - your sailors have been robbed by professionals.
Track the thieves down

The fleeing footprints are easily found. The tracks of the thieves' limping leader stand out in the dust. The grazing light of the setting sun highlights the path for your huntsmen and leads them away from the town and closer to its river, where tracks disappear in the water. The hills rise sharply on the other side.
Look for a ford to cross on foot

A safe passage! The crew's expertise shines as they rapidly spot a shallow part in the river and cross it without much inconvenience. They go up the sharp hill of the opposite bank and happen upon a vast enclosed field: a pen for horse breeding. A quick discussion with the owner confirms that the thieves stole several animals mere hours ago. The land beyond is barren and unfit for explorers on foot. Your crew needs horses.
Attempt to catch wild horses

The tamed horses easily catch up with your prey. Your hunters lasso the wild animals and break them before launching them through the barren plains. The blurry hot air parts to reveal the thieves' horses, whose speed is no match for wild ones. Your riders surround them and the menace of their number and drawn pistols hushes any resistance. The sailors, satisfied and avenged, retrieve their loot and entrust the scoundrels to the local law.

Your sailors are not made to catch land animals. The hunt ends in failure, the most your crew saw of a wild horse being weathered tracks in the dry roads. Instead of leading your hunters to a herd, the tracks drive them to a run-down town of wooden buildings -several houses and a single saloon-, its lanterns brightening with the growing darkness. Night is well on its way and tracking the thieves seems almost impossible now.
Ask the locals for help

The locals agree to help. Your diplomat carefully brings the subject of thieves to a man of imposing authority, the sheriff in charge of the small town. The modus operandi is familiar to him: a local gang is famous for their sneaking around foreign businessmen, but he never would have imagined they'd be so bold as to rob a ship. If the robbery was today, he says, the thieves are sure to come and celebrate at the saloon tonight.
Wait on the town's balconies, ready for an ambush

A clean job. As soon as the thieves come into sight, your sailors stealthily lay their firearms on the rail guards of balconies and aim and fire in rapid succession. The shots resonate through the quiet town: one shot, one permanent sleeper. When the sound and smell of gunshots settle down, the sheriff salutes your crew's help in getting rid of local pests and ensures the sailors that their reputation will be made known through the West.

Rout. Your sailors fire as soon as the gang comes into view, taking little time to aim and even less to observe their targets. The bullets graze past the thieves and upset their horses, who rear and jump before running away with their riders. A night drizzle starts falling and soon drowns their tracks. That's as far as the crew's efforts, notable but inefficient, can go.
Wait at the saloon, ready for a fight

Honour and wages are retrieved.When the gang slams the saloon's doors open, the place is devoid of its usual chirpy atmosphere. Moon rays disclose the presence of your crew, sat on every possible chair and table and stair step and already reaching for their guns. The fight is brief. Your sailors submerge the thieves and drag them outside, roped and gagged, and salute the sheriff before heading back to the ship with the satisfaction of a job well done.

Your crew is no match for the criminals. When the gang barges into the saloon, the sailors are still arguing over how to handle the fighting in such a closed space. The fight is short-lived. Your sailors lack the rough training and ability of their opponents and can barely fling insults at them, even less punches. The beaten crew is thrown outside and scampers away from the town - very aware of how lucky they are to still be alive.

Your crew is held responsible for the deserters' actions. Instead of probing around to get an idea of the runaways' reputation, your diplomat immediately asks about the thieves. The men are well-known in the worst way and the locals are shocked to hear your crew hosted them, regardless of the theft - the sailors are forced to leave when surrounded by stern-looking gunslingers. The track ends here. More than money, your sailors have lost morale.
Avoid trouble and simply give up

So much effort for such a meagre reward. Feeling the pressure of unseen stares, your crew avoids the shady town and backs away to the harbour city and their ship. Better to decide on your own to withdraw than to be forced to, the sailors tell themselves. Frustration nibbles their thoughts as they set sail.
Buy horses from the breeder
You can choose either to rent or buy a mount.
Confirm

The animals catch up with your prey in no time! In a flurry of dust and whinnying, the mounts assail the barren plains. The blurry hot air parts to reveal the thieves, perched atop horses already exhausted from their mishandling. Your riders surround them and the menace of their number and drawn pistols hushes any resistance. The sailors, satisfied and avenged, retrieve their loot and entrust the scoundrels to the local law.
Cancel

Your crew will make do on its own. The price for the withered mares reeks of scam and your sailors refuse to pay a single pound for the animals. Their observations might be influenced by the light weight of their purses.
Get on your horses

Your crew finds no guarantee of safe crossing. The sailors quickly get tired of the senseless search: the river's depth cannot be appraised by their untrained eyes, and each segment of the water seems both deep and shallow. The crew is too reluctant to try its luck, and abandons its search, disgruntled.
Create a raft to cross the river

A safe passage! The raft is basic but sturdy, and it crosses the river without losing so much as a plank. The crew boards the opposite bank safely and climbs the hill rising right beyond it. On the other side, they happen upon a vast enclosed field: a pen for horse breeding. A quick discussion with the owner confirms that the thieves stole several animals mere hours ago. The land beyond is barren and unfit for explorers on foot. Your crew needs horses.

The raft can't even float. Your sailors bind logs and dead branches together, binding them with sturdy knots but little knowledge of how to actually assemble the ropes. The raft's apparent stability tricks the builders into climbing onto it, and the raft swirls over the river, wobbling under the weight of sailors and the pressure of the current, before breaking and diving straight into the icy water. Few sailors can be rescued from the wreckage.

No tracks are found. The bustling harbour and the late evening insist on hiding the thieves' tracks. Your sailors are not skilled enough to pick up the faint trail inside the town itself, but they might have better luck around its outskirts.
Keep searching

Finally, tracks to follow! Amidst the numerous footprints left by your sailors, your best huntsmen manage to find the dotted lines left in the dust by the fleeing thieves. There's no mistaking the bent pattern of their limping leader. The prints waddle to the nearest river, where they fade in the water.
Isn't this humiliation enough? Your crew keeps foraging through the outskirts of town, but they still cannot find any tracks.
Stop these futile efforts

Your purser protests but the decision is final. Going after the thieves in a territory they seem to know by heart while the crew itself is in foreign territory? The risk will not be taken. As the ship sails away from the harbour and the villains it hosts, your sailors mourn the plundered funds.
Let them be

Your purser protests but the decision is final. Going after the thieves in a territory they seem to know by heart while the crew itself is in foreign territory? The risk will not be taken. As the ship sails away from the harbour and the villains it hosts, your sailors mourn the plundered funds.
Of Unsound Mind

The man spasms, eyes rolling, before finally falling unconscious. His mania had come suddenly, with eight men needed to pacify, and bind him to the mast. Some say he is possessed by daemons and must be done rid of. The officers, less credulous, seek a surer explanation. The only way to silence a worsening quarrel, is to find a solution.
Enlist the aid of the hypnotist

The crew are delighted the man has returned to his normal self. The hypnotist used a pendulum to induce him into deep sleep, before imparting subliminally, some choice words. Within days the fellow is happily back at work. All are buoyant that such a severe case was so artfully cured!
Examine the cause of this wildness in him

It is a superb recovery in the circumstances. The examination uncovers a bluish contusion under the hair. 'We are to act swiftly or he shall die!' says the doctor, as he bores a drill into the man's cranium. Once the blood is drained, the resultant hole is covered with a silver coin, and the head beswaddled with bandages. The man is fully recovered within a few days, and the crew greatly impressed by the actions of the doctor.

The whole examination takes too long, 'though a bluish contusion is found under the hair. 'I must act or he shall soon die!' gulps the doctor, but then proceeds to faff nervously through a medicine bag, until the poor man dies on the operating table. 'You did the best you could,' a colleague offers, but there is a hollowness to it.

The patient grabs the doctor's head and smashes it against the table. The doctor was tapping his knee to check reflex, when the devil cut loose. 'He wants putting out of his misery,' a sailor cries, once the man is wrestled to the deck again. So they cut his throat. Attention turns to the doctor, but he is a doctor no more. Injury has rendered him insensible; an eight-year-old boy trapped in the body of a man!

Hellish horror ensues, as the doctor insists on checking if 'ought is stuck in the throat'. As he prises open the lion's jaws, the daemon creature lurches up into his throat. So frenzied is this vampiric assault, that there is little the crew can do but to raise their pistols to the gruesomeness. When the gunsmoke clears, doctor and patient lie dead, entwined and contorted beneath a bloody dew.
Try to calm the crew, and pray the man recovers

The crew are convinced by the chaplain that god has a plan for this man. They agree to bind him to his bed while the chaplain prays for his fast recovery. After two weeks he still suffers gaps in his memory, and a paralysis of the face, but thanks are given to the lord above that he is otherwise his usual self.

The sailors are partially convinced there is a spiritual explanation for his deranged behaviour, but insist on chaining him to his bed. 'He must have done something terrible in the eyes of God,' they say. Despite all hope for his fast recovery, he dies not two days later, his malady forever a mystery.

The faithless crew will not trust this to God, but can neither agree if the possessed man should be thrown to sea, as desired by the sailors, or permitted a chance to see out his ordeal, as demanded by the officers.
Side with the officers and warn the sailors to cooperate or suffer the consequences

The sailors would not dare mutiny, of course, and return to their stations. At first they fear the bed-ridden man will commit some terrible act while they sleep. But they need not have worried, since he dies of the unexplained malady not two days later.

The sailors are outraged and their response is immediate. In greater numbers they overwhelm and restrain the officers, while the sickly subject of their fury is bound and thrown into the deep. Confidence in the leadership of the expedition is undermined and the possibility of further trouble seems never far away.
Convince the officers the needs of the many must prevail over the needs of the few

No officer can deny the logic of the argument, yet, when the man is bound and thrown overboard they cannot help but show their grief it is for no fault of his own, and that none had knowledge with which to better help him.

'It's a bally disgrace! You dishonour a gentleman!' say the officers, as the man is bound and thrown overboard, 'such incompetence shall be reported to the highest authority!' Not only is a man lost, but the expedition brought into disrepute.
Guard him round the clock in his cabin

There was little for the guards to report, but occasionally 'quelling the mad dog' with liquor. After a fortnight, the poor man recovers with no recollection of anything, and while his hand is partially paralysed, he is still able to perform his usual duties.

The damn guards are found with sacks over their heads. They swear they did not see their attacker, but weakly-tied hands suggest collusion. Of course the patient's bed is vacant, and he seems to be missing, permanently. After that, rumours circulate, and no-one seems to have any trust in anyone else.
Ignore the officers and get rid of him before it's too late

The officers react with disgust to your decision to toss him overboard, and state in no uncertain terms that the whole matter will be reported. But the sailors are quite obviously relieved that his demonic presence has been exorcised.
The Seven-Year Itch

The crew are beset by insatiable and painful itching! From lieutenants down to pigeon-keepers, they twist and turn in their bunks and cannot sleep. It is affecting their capacity to carry out the most basic duties, something must be done!
Wash more often!

Washing a splendid idea at sea? Who knew?! The itching is very soon forgotten, as the sailors cavort through rainbows of expurgating bubbles. The rich perfume below deck is a welcome reminder of family and bygone days.
Analyse the symptoms

'Only jellyfish!' says the cultivated doctor cheerfully. 'Our refreshing swim at that cove appears to be the cause. It must have been rife with their larvae!' The crew marvel at the clever diagnosis, and as the itching subsides, bask in the pioneering case-study they have performed for the benefit of humankind.
The red welts seem to perplex the doctor. 'There is evidence of the parasitic,' he splutters as he peers through his magnifying glass, 'but then it could be nothing at all!'
Examine the cabins for some sort of parasite
There are bedbugs everywhere! There must be something that can be done to exterminate these disc-bodied hangers-on!
Refurbish the cabins

The matter is craftily 'put-to-bed'. Despite the time-consuming upheaval, the crew are surprised to have their cabins so well refurbished. 'They're too soft on us,' says a jolly cove inspecting the new bunks, but my britches haven't itched all day.'

What dreary decor!' says the Lieutenant tartly. Matters deteriorate when some ill-fashioned bunks collapse. 'I'd rather have the itching back,' says an exhausted-looking sailor. Like others, he has to sleep out on the hard decking, until some competent craftsmen can come aboard.
Simply change the sheets

It is a job half-done. For most the problem goes away, but some must live with the itching. Wherever the bugs' nasty little hidey-hole is, it must still reel with lousy punters, each telling stories of the sailor blood they drained the night before.

They cannot see the wood for the trees! Evidence of fleas would be everywhere to the right pair of eyes. Two weeks pass, and murine typhus breaks out. Rashes, fever and vomiting grip the fleas' hosts, who are never able to find the cause of their itching agony.
Have the afflicted bathe in holy water

The priest's most divine bottle does the trick. 'This water is indeed holy!' he says, as the fearsome muscovite vodka from 1791 is uncorked and slapped over the itches of the queuing sailors. 'Shame to use it like this, but I'd rather sleep,' he cackles.

'Is nothing sacred anymore?' Says the priest, who turns up his nose at the suggestion of using his water for something so humdrum. 'The lord hath bigger fish to fry,' he says pointedly. As well as the vile and incessant itching, the crew now have a parsimonious priest to contend with.

The doctor is a demented quack. When the condition is established correctly as crusted scabies - contagious, but hardly dangerous - the doctor's experiment is for the affected to bathe in an acid solution. Needless to say, his victims do not survive their injuries. When the expedition returns, it is entirely possible he may be stripped of his profession.
Find somewhere to stop and be rid of it

Sand and sun is a panacea! An acute sense of direction leads the ship to an island paradise. A freshwater lagoon relieves the itching, and the much-needed relaxation will stand all in good stead for the journey ahead.

Bringing contagion to port might be a bad idea. The itching is at its worst by the time the expedition reaches the bustling alien seaport, something the local authorities don't fail to notice. The harbour-master's tug escorts you to quarantine. How do you escape?
Lie that the sickness isn't contagious

The lie works like a charm. A doctor promptly comes aboard to confirm this hypothesis. Although she sternly points out the condition is contagious after all, she also recognises it to be a mild complaint. 'Crabs,' the translator says, face flushing. The crew are too relieved to feel embarrassed.
It is obvious you are lying, and the authorities are not impressed. They allow several days to pass, without any word on your ship's release, adversely affecting the morale of your crew.
Threaten them into letting you go

They don't want any trouble. A doctor comes aboard ship and goes nervously about his business. Although the atmosphere is somewhat cagey, medicines for your crew's skin conditions are provided, and the expedition can continue on its way.

You underestimate them. Two surprise warships hove round the landspit and close in to firing range. There is no choice but to run. As your ship crashes wildly out between jetties, the escort ship pincers, and opens fire. The effect is catastrophic. Your modest vessel flees in tatters, and many good sailors are dead or wounded. For the rest, the itching is set to continue.
Await quarantine

It's a long time before the authorities deal with you, with bureaucracy seemingly a way of life here. When you finally have access to a medical professional, there is already a post-mortem to be conducted. It appears chemicals leeched into the water supply and caused the rashes and sickness. With the water changed, the others recover, but it cannot redeem the loss of a life.

It's impossible for your aimless navigators to concentrate. The expedition fidgets wildly off course, with no land in sight. Meanwhile the assassin bugs continue to spread their dreadful disease. Even they'd probably make better navigators! Then there wouldn't have to be quite so much death!
Let them itch, it's common at sea

It is a particularly awful itch however. The disgusting lice infesting the ship, and discomfort thereof has many questioning the worth of your expedition. There is only so much scratching a crew can take before they lose all appetite for the journey ahead.
Parasitic Infestation
These parasites must have come from the marsh goo; all that waist-high wading. Now they nestle deep in your crew, who, at risk of harm from their own madcap cures, really need professional help!
Bathe them in alcohol
Treat the afflicted
Hope the problem goes away.

A delectable disinfectant! The suffering take immense pleasure scouring themselves in a whacking great tub of the stuff. Indeed, so diverting is this new form of alcohol absorption, that even those without parasites take turns.

The doctor concocts a panacea, which not only purges the belly-dwelling roundworm, but more besides. Garlic, wormwood, and lemon quietly see off a myriad other complaints of your spoon-dodging sailors.
The doctors disagree. 'Madam! Bloodletting gives our patients only a fifty-fifty chance!' says one. 'Sir, tinctures are seldom beneficial OR effective on parasites!' says the other.
It does go away, eventually. 'My arm looked like a wormcake for a while,' one sailor laments, 'but that little smattering of holes filled-up with pus now - signs my body is winning the war.'
Mass amputation for all?! The festering parasites have gnawed their way to bone! Limbs must be chopped, or else their bodies shall rattle with bemaggoted cavities!
Try the latest tincture
Risk bloodletting the patients
Let nature take its course
A fine placebo. As if by magic, the intestinal worms lose the will to go on. The doctor freely admits this is more likely down to positive patient attitude, than his revolting tincture.

The unpleasant medicine doesn't help. Constant trips to the privy are now the only release for your bug-ridden crew. The doctor admits to the failure of the tincture, but thankfully has something for diarrhoea.
The tincture is poison! Having seen their first shipmate choke on his dose, the rest decide they'd rather live with a six-foot tapeworm in their bellies.
Somehow it works, and the patients are rid of the parasite. The doctor seems unsurprised, 'human physiology may be complex, but treatment need not be.' A pretty vague case summary, but who cares?!

Perfect preparation for amputation! At least that's what your crazed doctor would have you believe. Once her macabre experiment is concluded there is surely only one course of action for the afflicted...the crew are aghast.
It does go away, eventually. 'My arm looked like a wormcake for a while,' one sailor laments, 'but that little smattering of holes filled-up with pus now - signs my body is winning the war.'
Mass amputation for all?! The festering parasites have gnawed their way to bone! Limbs must be chopped, or else their bodies shall rattle with bemaggoted cavities!
Have the doctor amputate
Let nature take its course
As good as could be expected. Out with parasites, in with polished peg legs and helpful hook-hands. The crew look not nearly as enthusiastic as you might think however.

Extraordinary that you trusted that quack! She is sideshow surgeon, carving up her victims with the zeal of a ripper, and the accuracy of a pissing schoolboy. At least the screams will die away soon enough...
Nothing can save them. Though a mercy that they may choose their manner of death - unmolested by the ship's quack - it is death nonetheless. The parasite has sucked the life from your expedition.
Cut or Lift

Sailor under the mast! Weeks of harsh weather have taken their toll on the ship and the violent gusts of wind of this morning have toppled the mizzenmast. For a moment the ropes tying it to the other masts hold it in place, but there is only so much weight they can take: they break with a snap, letting the mizzenmast plummet on the deck. A sailor now wails, his leg caught under a pole twice his size.
Cover the leg with a mix of water and soap and pull it away

The sailor is easily pulled from under the mast. The foamy water allows the crushed leg to slither away from the debris and the limb emerges covered in rainbow bubbles and bloody splinters. The man will live and maybe, with a miracle or two, his leg will mend.
Cut the leg with a bone saw

An extreme but commendable choice. The sailor is given rum to drink and cloth to bite before he is held in place, his leg bound with a tight tourniquet. The doctor's labour is gruesome and the man can feel the grinding cuts as they tear through him, and he screams through the cloth and he howls and he roars - and yet the doctor stays composed and focused. When the leg is finally cut and the sailor dragged away, the crew feels that they are in capable hands.

Butchery. The doctor's hands tremble more than his victim does, and the saw draws zigzags in the flesh, each cut unable to connect with the previous ones. The trapped sailor's screams become whimpers, then silence. The doctor has to be stopped before he can ruin any more of the unfortunate corpse, and his blood-clad figure sends a warning to whoever might ever need his help in the future.
Lift the mast with a makeshift lever

The man is freed. Using one of the partners broken by the mast, the crew fits the sturdy pieces of timber between the deck and the fallen mast, adding plank after plank in the opening and gradually raising the mast with ropes and pulleys tied to the mainmast. They manage to lift the mast long enough to free the sailor, and the doctor immediately tends to his crushed leg.

The vague idea of a lever never becomes real. The sailors try to lift the mizzenmast by rolling logs underneath, but the huge wooden pole is far too heavy for its rolling movement to be controlled. The mast lurches forward and rolls from the sailor's leg to his chest, pushing his insides out. The view stays with the sailors for days before they can finally reach a decent harbour, get rid of the broken mast, and clean up the grisly mess underneath.
Bottles Found in the Sea

Castaways request your help, but where could they be? Shark-baiting is a common distraction for your sailors. Their latest catch provided much more entertainment than expected: in its belly was a bottle and in the bottle were three sheets of paper, each a copy of the same message in different languages. Piecing together the documents to make up for their weathered content, the crew can make out a call for help and a latitude, but nothing more.
Examine the entrails of the shark for clues

The stomach of the shark reveals where it's been. Glittering corals, exotic scales, characteristic fish bones. Your doctors finish their inspection of the shark's entrails and confirm the destination: to the Southern coral barriers! When the ship reaches the correct latitude, several islands litter the horizon. The crew hesitates to come closer. The water is shallower than usual and filled with sharp coral reefs.
Navigate closer to the islands and their reefs

Your ship avoids the deadly reefs and finds the castaways! The vessel groans as it swims through the limpid waters, the deepest corals reflecting its shadow as it avoids them. It takes a short while to find the castaways, entrenched among the dunes of a secluded beach and sprouting from it with squeals of joy and disbelief. Their captain offers his unalienable loyalty and your crew gladly welcomes the newcomers.

The ship cannot pass the underwater barrier. Despite your navigator's efforts, the ship bumps against the coral reef - the manoeuvre is too complex and too risky for her. The crew is forced to turn its back to the paradisiacal islands. Whether the castaways were real, whether they were indeed stranded here, they will never know.
Stay away and have the look-out search for castaways

Found them! Your look-out shows their brilliance when they spot the thin smoke line of a campfire in the distance. A dinghy is sent to retrieve the castaways and comes back filled to the brim with men in overgrown beards, torn clothes, and awed faces. Their captain pledges himself to your crew and, once shaved and washed, the castaways prove themselves to be excellent sailors and even better companions.

The look-out draws a blank. Scanning the islands from afar is a difficult exercise, made even harder by the lack of experience. The crew soon realizes that it will never find anyone from such a distance. Reluctant to risk the ship's integrity over the mere possibility of the castaways' existence, your sailors choose to leave and forget.

The homemade autopsy is a mess. The shark's entrails are cut along with their contents and spilled over the deck is a nauseous mass of gore and artefacts of unknown origin. The doctor cannot make sense of the anarchy he created.
Interpret the patterns in the shark's entrails

Relentless faith guides the most deserving. In the spilled gut of the shark, your navigators see the shapes of islands, your doctors see the patterns of life forms, your boatswain sees the promise of rewards. Driven by an inner force beyond simple greed, the crew sails past coral reefs and insidious currents and finds the island on which the castaways had been waiting for rescue. Their relief is glorious and their captain promises to serve your crew!

There is nothing to find but deceit. Your cooper burns sage among the remains of the shark and sniffs the lumpy smoke. If forces do talk to him, they might have been beyond what he could handle: he suddenly pounces on the closest sailor, crushing her throat between his hands. Three more fall before his frenzy drives him overboard with an otherworldly scream. The castaways are cursed and the sailors mourn their comrades for the rest of the trip.
Divination? Let's just stop now

Shark, bottle and messages are thrown overboard. Several sailors protest against the rash decision and would have preferred to exhaust all options before giving up, or at least keep the messages to share them at the next harbour. The imagined blame and grief of the castaways haunt them for a while.
Map the islands matching the partial coordinates

The search defines a searchable area. Many islands match the latitude but much less could be mapped on an actual shipping route. By deducing where the castaways' ship might have gone, your navigators identify a handful of islands which could host the castaway. After two weeks of smooth sailing, your ship reaches the area: a necklace of islands linked by strands of deadly coral reef.

Your navigator is overwhelmed by the mass of possibilities. Unable to find a proper searching method and define a list of reasonable proportions, they abandon their task and admit the crew might as well try to work out the contents of the entrails. It is said as a joke, however, some sailors consider the idea.
There's no time to spare for such things
The bottle and its messages are thrown back into the sea. The crew's regrets drift away with the bottle and the castaways are soon forgotten.
The Preacher

Your chaplain is going overboard with his preaching. Blaming the expedition's mishaps and hazards on the supposed heresy of the ship's officers, the man of faith manages to rouse the gradual distrust and anger of the sailors. His preaching is now part of the crew's daily routine. His words find echo in the mouths of the sailors, and your lieutenants can see their authority slipping away.
Demonstrate that his doubts are fuelled by a mental illness

The man of faith belongs to an asylum. Your doctor interrupts the chaplain's daily sermon and accuses him of megalomania, listing the traits of the madness: desire for attention, desire for control, desire to rouse the paranoia of others in order to match one's own. The portrait is a perfect depiction of the chaplain, and, despite their former affection for the man, the sailors agree that he should be sedated with laudanum for the rest of the trip.

The doctor only proves his own paranoia. Your doctor interrupts the chaplain's daily sermon with a loud declaration, stating that the man of faith is, in fact, a soul tormented by a mental illness. With all eyes on him, your doctor utters a list of personal opinions rather than medical facts, and the chaplain welcomes his doubts with benevolence. His influence flourishes and your lieutenants have to make do with him for the rest of the trip.
Discredit him in a direct confrontation

Your diplomat has a greater way with words. She silently enters the lower deck during the chaplain's daily preaching and waits in a corner of a room. When the man of faith finally loses his nerve and asks her what she wants, she lists two hours worth of the chaplain's arguments and, without pause, offers counterpoints for each of them. The humiliation is magnificent and the chaplain's babbling defence convinces the crew of his puerility. They lose interest.

Your diplomat was not ready to face the chaplain. She confronts the preacher before the crew and flaunts her interpretation of the chaplain's mistakes, stating how wrong he is without taking into account the weeks of argument he had built with his followers. Her diatribe convinces none but herself, and the chaplain simply remarks that her anger is proof of his being right. Your lieutenants have to make do with his whims for the rest of the trip.
Simply punish him without taking measures against his ideas

Not the most diplomatic solution, but it works. Trusted sailors interrupt the chaplain during his daily preaching and drag him to the upper deck, where your first mate welcomes the man of faith with a devoted flogging. The display of violence mostly proves the preacher's point, but the menace of the officers' ire is greater than the crew's distrust in them. The trip resumes in a climate of tension.
Taken In, Broken Out

Behind bars! The prolonged stay of your ship in this harbour is not a willed one. Obscure laws were breached and your whole crew was arrested under the pretence that borders, whose nature remains unknown, were not respected. Heavily armed foreigners lead your crew through the sinuous roads of their city and into the local jail, and after passing by a row of freshly hanged criminals, the sailors are locked up. Only two guards keep watch, their heads bobbing with fatigue. Are they underestimating your crew?
Poison the guards!

Two guards are not enough to resist your science. The doctor brings out a sachet of vials and packets and produces leathery pouches filled with white powders, some matte, some glittering like sugar. He mixes a bit of this one and a bit of that one, gauging measures with the eye of the seasoned practitioner, then calls to the guards. When the unsuspecting wardens are close enough, the doctor blows the mixture in their face. The men drop dead!
Disguise as guards and escort the rest of the crew

The escape is flawless. Two of your sailors don the guards' uniforms and drag the rest of the chained crew through the prison. When they are stopped at the exit, they mimic the local accent, briefly explain the liberation, and kick one of the chained sailors for good measure. The legitimate wardens buy the lie! It takes an even greater effort to refrain from laughing before reaching the ship and leaving the port.

An attempt way beyond their ability. Two sailors put on the guards' uniforms and lead the crew through the prison, until legitimate guards stop them and enquire about the strange cortege. The disguised men's fidgety attitude and suspiciously foreign accent is enough to convince the wardens to check their original cell: the bodies are found and with them comes the heavy charge of murder. The following day, the trial is held.
Offer to pay a fine, however high it might be
Confirm

The price is high, but fair. Most of the expedition's budget is squandered in the brutal fine and if the crew is cleared of their charges, they find themselves forced to ration their supplies for the rest of the trip. The doctor and his accursed ideas are blamed and the man is turned into a scapegoat: his rations are regularly stolen, damaging his health and abilities, and, worse, the crew blatantly avoids his treatments.
Cancel

Who would accept such a meager payment? Murder is not a subject to be triffled with and the foreign court makes its opinion clear: your crew will pay in the hardest way possible. To show that they value life more than your sailors, the judges impose a non-lethal punishment and insist on this point, devising a program of forced labour and precise observation to make sure the sailors suffer as much as possible without dying. Months of hell follow before the crew can leave.
Pretend these actions were a demand from the higher-ups and have the crew repudiate Her Majesty

That lie is believable, but it doesn't erase your crew's crimes. The foreign judges put aside any idea of death sentence and focus on finding a punishment befitting the crime: the crew is arranged into a procession and made to cross the city in chains, while chanting the ill-will of their Queen. Their patriotism tainted, the sailors never dare to pronounce her name again.

Who would believe such an obvious lie? Why would their Queen ask for such a menial task as poisoning oversea guards? To match the crime, the crew's lieutenants are forced to drink hemlock solutions and trapped in a single cell with the rest of the crew. The lieutenants gag and wheeze for days of agony, their skin puffing and their muscles stiffening in impossible positions until their breathing itself is locked into place. Only then are the sailors allowed to leave.
Avoid drawing any attention and sneak outside

The perfect crime! Despite their numbers, your sailors manage to sneak through the prison and into the streets, where they become shadows under the moonless night. Led by your most competent hunters, they creep through back alleys and backyards until the obscurity delivers them below their ship. Feeling like the protagonists of an adventure novel and revelling in the sentiment, they leave the harbour in the gliding vessel - all lights off and no sound made.

They are caught! Your sailors' lack of discretion is awkward and it is only a matter of minutes before a patrol spots them. Without any prepared disguise or lie, they are instantly arrested and, worse, the bodies of the poisoned guards are found on the way back to their cell. The next morning, they are judged not for their meager trespassing, but for actual murder.

The doctor showcases his ignorance. He produces a pouch of arsenic before calling the guards. When the jailers are close enough, the doctor is ready to blow the powder in their face - however, his lack of knowledge of the poison's properties backfires: the soft inhalation of the doctor is enough to bring the highly volatile poison to his lips, and he leaps back, coughing and wheezing. The guards immediately understand this was attempted murder.
Dig an escape tunnel!

A nice display of craftsmanship. The crew digs a tunnel with skill, taking care of reinforcing the structure and analysing the soil's nature as they progress. They avoid the most friable sections of the city's ground and emerge on the coast, exactly as calculated. Your ship is not too far but a frigate guards it. Its lights are off, the guards might be sleeping and not actually keeping watch.
Stealthily sail away

Swift as a whisper. Your sailors embark on the ship and deploy its sails in an excruciatingly slow manner, timing their flapping and clinking with the melody of the backwash. The vessel creaks softly and lets the sea take it, drifting away from the harbour with delicate movements of to and fro - soon the city is but a point on the horizon, and the sailors allow themselves to explode in a clamour of celebration.

Ridiculously visible. Your sailors tiptoe past the guarding frigate, their shadows stretching across the whole deck, their stressed whispers ringing through the night. As a testimony to their poor hunting skill, it takes a barrel in their cheeks for them to realize they have been spotted. The next morning, the judges' verdict takes into account the escape attempt and condemn half of your crew to a month of forced labour.
Offer to pay a fine instead
Confirm

Bribery is a reasonable option. The payment offered satisfies the judges, who agree to let your sailors go. The crew mutters about the absurd trial and its even more absurd resolution, but their relief shows.
Cancel

Not enough. The judges scoff at your attempt to bribe them with a so-called fine, and advise your crew to aim for a higher amount next time. To show they are not cheap, they extend their penalty to two months of forced labour and place the sailors under the tightest surveillance. The two months are a mixture of menial and unrewarding tasks and frequent and unwarranted whipping.
Force your crew into complying with the unreasonable demand

The crew complies. Following their superiors' orders, the sailors accept the judges' penalty and fulfil their obligations to the best of their abilities. One month of forced labour seems harsh even for the local population, who supports the crew's effort and vouch for their liberation: the crew earns an early release, tired but touched by the unexpected appreciation.
